candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Yes. Yes.

'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've worked extensively on brand communication and content strategy development. Can you walk me through a specific example of how you tailored messaging for a startup client, and what key factors you considered in that process?  

", 'Interviewee: I worked for a startup called Peacefully, which helps individuals work through end of life necessities and

'], ['Interviewer: That sounds like a challenging but important project. How did you approach the tone and style of the messaging for Peacefully, considering the sensitive nature of the services they provide?  

', "Interviewee: Yeah. That was a that's a great question. And I, uh, what we did was we focused on being we looked around, first of all, competitors and saw how, uh, the other businesses that were in the same space spoke because, uh, one way that we recognize to stand out was have distinction in our brand voice. And we recognized that there was, uh, a lot of coldness in their tone. So we really worked on being as empathetic as possible, especially as you mentioned given the sensitive nature of the work. And so we looked at every communication on Instagram, etcetera, and made sure that it sounded like a human being, and that it also sounded like it was, um, even though we were providing necessary information, it was put in such a way that it was considered of where a person may be in their life in terms of potentially having just experienced a loss.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you put a lot of thought into that process. How did you measure the effectiveness of this new brand voice and messaging approach, particularly in terms of user engagement or feedback?  

", 'Interviewee: Yeah. We primarily looked at reviews and actually we interfaced a lot with our, uh, with our client base because, essentially, we were pretty small and we and the first couple people who are using the platform were, um, were essentially the first. So we were able to communicate directly with them. Some of them we actually knew personally. And we got a lot of important feedback about how the flow of information and questions was designed. Uh, we and we we, uh, of course, we were cautious of the fact that the sample size was not huge and but we did insist that people were unsparing in their criticism and then we factored in their feedback. And as time went on and we got more and more feedback, we were then able to test the changes that we were making against, uh, how people were feeling about the content.

'], ["Interviewer: That's a very hands-on and user-centric approach to feedback. Shifting focus a bit, I'd like to discuss your experience with SEO best practices. Can you describe a particularly challenging SEO problem you encountered at White Glove Financial and how you solved it?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Our goal at White Glove Financial was to write new content that would live inside of a platform and, uh, that we had built. And, uh, actually, we had acquired it. We had acquired it from another company, but then we were refining it for our needs. Uh, the company was, uh, the the goal of the company was for financial advisors to stay in touch with clients and recruit new business. And, uh, one of the ways to do that is basically to be introducing topics to people that were, um, that were sufficiently interesting and but would also lead to the conclusion that they could not master the subject themselves. They had to speak to a financial adviser. So what we did was we would have content that lived on our own platform, but we would share it on social media. And I would say the challenge with Facebook social media is, first of all, just from a back end standpoint, they are skeptical of platforms like ours, so we really had to be rigorous in conforming to their, um, their proprietary standards, um, because if you were too boring, uh, in your in any aspect of your content, it would not share that content widely, and it was really working against what we were trying to do for those financial advisors. So suffice to say that that that course that position required a crash course in Facebook SEO in particular, uh, now Meta, but we weren't really primarily using Instagram as much as we were trying to use Facebook because we recognized that that was more in line with where the customer base primarily was interacting on social media.

"], ["Interviewer: It's interesting how you tailored the content to not only be engaging but also to drive a specific action. Given the challenges with Facebook's algorithm and standards, can you elaborate on some of the specific strategies or techniques you found most effective in ensuring your content was both engaging and compliant with their standards?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. I would say the way to do that within Facebook is that you're essentially just answering line by line as you probably know, um, both, uh, a subject title and then an article title. And so what you would do was, of course, you'd have the article title be something that would be outward facing and engaging. But then sort of the subject title would be, uh, basically a keyword rich thing that Facebook would recognize, um, as something that should be shared widely if someone was, uh, the type of person who was reading, for example, a lot of financial information on Facebook or even the Wall Street Journal, for example, we recognize. Those are the types of people who, um, were, you know, a big part of our demographic. Because the whole point of the financial advisor situation is that you are trying to get people to realize they don't know enough about a subject. And on that end, ultimately, um, while the content was while the goal of the content was this was definitely to be clear, It was also to emphasize the many pitfalls of trying to manage financial, uh, advice and, uh, management of one's portfolio by oneself. So the the goal was definitely not to be, um, muddy, but it was essentially to communicate the the the the crucial importance of getting these decisions right and how also how much of a relief it is when those decisions have been outsourced to someone who is ostensibly a professional because essentially, the financial advisor's pitch is that you don't, um, you know, you don't get get into a limousine with someone who's never driven before, and if you've never driven before yourself, you don't just get behind the wheel of a car and start driving. Um, and and ultimately that, um, while on a surface level, financial decisions are simple from the standpoint of just investing in index funds has has been the operative wisdom for 20 to 30 years. There are also so many decisions underneath, uh, retirement investing. For example, um, management of one's home and estate, education saving and spending, etcetera, um, and then the tax implications of all that that one should be thinking about. And and the goal was to emphasize how a holistic approach like that is so much more advantageous than just thinking, oh, I'm gonna buy um, whatever index fund at a regular price and blah blah blah, and that's all I need to do to be in a good situation financially.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to content framing and targeting is quite strategic. Shifting back to the technical side, could you explain how you approached the technical aspects of SEO, such as on-page optimization or site structure, to ensure the content you were creating for the financial advisors' platform was not only engaging but also highly discoverable by search engines?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. Although I think I've kind of done that a few times, but I I guess basically, uh, when you're working, uh, in the back end in meta and you are it it in some part, this was a collaboration with with the, uh, people who had built the platform that we were then using at White Glove, which was, um, which, as I said, was proprietary, but would also allow financial advisors to not only share content via social media, but also keep track of their clients and prospects. It was basically one big dashboard. So, uh, but that the some of the decisions about how to optimize, uh, and get plugged in directly to Facebook and what they needed were being handled by the back end developing people who, uh, who were a separate team, and I was not necessarily a part of that team. They did ask me what what they would love to from me would and I was very simple in my response, which is just, hey. We need, um, we need stuff that looks professional, and we need stuff that looks like it's coming from the Wall Street Journal and other, uh, outlets that people trust because we just don't wanna look like, well, a very bad version of NerdWallet, for example. Um, so but but I will say that, uh, the most of the decisions for how to optimize, um, from a digital standpoint were, uh, were being handled by the back end development team because the goal was not to go viral on Facebook necessarily. The goal was to be much more, uh, personal and and informative and not really trying for fireworks, but really trying to simply just look professional and those that required, um, just building a system that talked to Facebook and answered all the questions and and looked like it was a professional outlet.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you had a strong focus on the user experience and the credibility of the content. Given your role in ensuring the content's professionalism and trustworthiness, how did you collaborate with the development team to maintain a balance between the visual and functional aspects of the platform, especially in terms of SEO considerations?  

", "Interviewee: Well, the platform was I there's a little bit of a lack of overlap here because the SEO considerations were, um, you know, but they were basically internally handled. And then when it came but when it came to actually, uh, the design of the of the interface itself, um, that it was important that financial advisers would have an easy time navigating that because those were our direct clients. Uh, we weren't dealing with people who were trying to reach financial advisers. We were dealing with financial advisers and and those people can be quite conservative in in their approach. So I would say the the abundance of focus was placed on simply having an easy to use professional looking sort of Charles Schwabbe type interface that, uh, the type of people who were our direct clients, which as I mentioned, were very conservative, basically mid market and small market financial professionals who were just trying to grow their business from 5 to 7 to 9 to 13. Uh, they could be sharing content on Facebook that was not just, hey, I'm a financial advisor, come talk to me, but was professional looking, um, and also, um, and also content that they could trust and that and that emphasize the right content goals, which is let's just get people in the door and start having a conversation regardless of where they're at in life, and especially if they're at a turning point in life, like getting their first job, getting married, etcetera.

"], ["Interviewer: It's interesting to see how the focus on user experience and trustworthiness extended to the platform's design and functionality. Given the conservative nature of the target audience, how did you approach the content strategy to ensure it resonated with financial advisors and helped them achieve their business growth goals?  

", "Interviewee: That's a great question. It was definitely something that we handled using, um, what what was happening at White Glove while I was there was we were leasing a a content platform, uh, that was widely used, um, and that we were paying a lot of money for, but that allowed advisers to share paywalled content, which was kind of the, uh, opportunity benefit that was being promoted to financial advisers and consequently to their clients, the type of people who, um, basically the incentive would be I'm gonna follow financial advisor x on Facebook because by doing so, I'll be able to read stuff on Forbes and Barron's, etcetera, uh, financial outlets that pay well their content. Bloomberg would be another example. Um, and we were getting away from that. We were we were having to do it ourselves. And so, um, so we we actually had an opportunity to spend 3 or 4 months surveying our current client base of financial advisors and asking them the type of content that they think would be good for their audience. Now we also recognize that they wouldn't necessarily be the best judges of that. Um, for example, uh, we got a lot of feedback about not including or even bothering to write anything about cryptocurrency. That's, you know, that's it was a type of thing that, um, that financial advisers were tired of hearing about, but at the same time, from a from a conversion standpoint in terms of bringing in new clients, it tested extremely highly after the fact for being the type of thing that that people were actually coming in the door and talking about. And that became particularly true as time went on and as we have now reached the point where there are Bitcoin ETFs and soon to be ether ETFs. This is the type of thing that, um, that at least the younger client base of financial advisers work with are definitely interested in diversifying their portfolio and especially given the state of the market right now, uh, in terms of being at an all time high. So, um, so to some degree, we were able to, uh, modulate and control the type of content that financial advisers would see and particularly the stuff that they wouldn't see, but it was also part of my job and our role as a company to convince them that the topics like LGBTQ would be another example that they might consider to be, um, outside of their purview and also potentially politically hazardous are also exactly the kind of things that a, get interest from people, and, b, may potentially grow a client base because, of course, with the younger generation, there are also more gay couples and things like that, and it's and it's financial advisers. Uh, once they use the platform would recognize that if they shared content about that, they could control who got to see it, um, and and and also who didn't get to see it so that they could be less conservative in their approach.

"], ["Interviewer: It's fascinating to see how you navigated the balance between the financial advisors' preferences and the actual audience engagement data. Given the success of introducing topics like cryptocurrency and LGBTQ finance, how did you measure the impact of these new content areas on the financial advisors' client acquisition and retention?  

", "Interviewee: That was just something that we would reach out, uh, after 6 months, uh, of being on the platform. Actually, we did a small survey at 3 months and then a bigger one at 6 months. And, uh, in addition to the daily feedback that we would be getting through private channels, things like emails and chat, etcetera, that we were, uh, that we were keeping in contact with financial advisers. But we also did a concerted survey to see how these people were feeling about their content. And then, um, and, of course, also ask them to rate the effectiveness of certain content. There were also it's was not a huge client base of financial advisors, so it was the type of people that our account team regularly interface with. And I would say it was a priority of mine to, um, to route as many of those calls over to me as possible and or to be interacting with, uh, the 2 women who were in charge of the account base to hear the anecdotes about how certain content was performing and others not. Um, you know, the the there was never it was never surprised that backdoor Roth conversions were of interest to people, but, uh, it was it was, um, heartening to hear that, uh, social issues were driving as much of the conversation.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you had a comprehensive approach to gathering feedback and measuring the impact of the content strategy. Given the success of this approach, how did you use these insights to further refine the content strategy and potentially explore new areas of focus for the financial advisors' platform?  

", "Interviewee: Well, I think you just answered the question. We we I would say it's not easy to say how we did that. Uh, that's just what we did. I mean, we we would, um, we would continue to write about basic issues, but, um, I think we recognize that what is a Roth IRA was not the kind of thing that would get the same feedback as something that was a little more incendiary, especially given that we were using social media. So I would say, um, I actually think from the beginning, we bit off a lot of of, uh, news verticals and

"], ['Interviewer: It sounds like you were able to identify and leverage the power of engaging and sometimes controversial topics to drive engagement and conversation. Given this shift in strategy, how did you ensure that the content remained informative and valuable to the audience, even when discussing more incendiary topics?  

', "Interviewee: Well, I wouldn't say we ever got 2 incendiary, but I would say that, uh, we we worked closely with a, uh, with a company that, um, uh, hired writers on someone's behalf when you were in charge of a team, and they turned out the the you were able to work with the same writer. You didn't get new ones all the time, so we were able to basically say, oh, this is our financial expert and they really get, uh, how we're writing, uh, how we're trying to write in a certain quasi journalistic tone, but but mostly on the informative side of things. And and then when we threw that person, um, a maybe more incendiary topic, and I don't think we ever did anything too incendiary, they knew to write it in our kind of brand voice because that was what that company in particular specialized in. And then I was there as a final judge of whether, uh, the content was adhering to our copy and voice guidelines.

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! ', 'Interviewee: You? Sure. Go ahead.

'], ["Interviewer: Great to hear! Let's dive into your resume. I see you've had extensive experience with Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS), particularly Greenhouse, Lever, and Oracle. Can you elaborate on how you've leveraged these systems to improve the hiring process, specifically in terms of data-driven decision-making and enhancing diversity and inclusion?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. So, um, uh, last I worked in Greenhouse, and, um, there are a lot of reports we used to pull, like, source of hire and, um, um, time to hire, time to fill, um, then conversion ratio. So these things help in, um, gauging that, uh, in your whole interview process. They talk about time to hire, then um, which step took the maximum time and then do the root cause analysis and then understand what's the problem and solve it so that you can decrease the time to hire. Same for, um, the time to fill that, you know, which steps are were there where lot of rejection happens. Say for that matter, if the rejection is happening between, um, recruiter call, like screening and hiring manager phone screen, that means screening needs to, um, get better. And then they sit with the hiring manager, talk again about the requirement, talk to them about keywords, and maybe target companies and any, um, and every knowledge around it and then improve the screening part. If the rejections are happening between the hiring managers, um, screening and then the, uh, full loop interviews, Then, uh, the calibration is the issue. Then we just, um, you know, we, uh, request the hiring manager that he may he or she may sit with the hiring team and talk about it, that why there is this gap. So this was about data driven approach, um, by using ATS, um, like, using their reporting systems. And if I talk about diversity and inclusion, again, uh, through ATS, we can pull reports where it says about the pipeline health that is it diverse or not, um, gender diverse or not, or other kind of diversity is included or not. Then we can accordingly take measures. Like, one of the measure we took around was, uh, in our internal panel, um, it was not necessarily the gender diverse. So we made a mandate that, um, it has to be gender diverse. So whenever a hiring manager used to provide us the interview panel, they have to, you know, share, um, agenda diverse panel for sure. Thank you.

"], ["Interviewer: That's a comprehensive approach to leveraging ATS for data-driven decision-making and diversity initiatives. When it comes to the reports you mentioned, such as source of hire and pipeline health, how do you ensure the accuracy and completeness of the data, especially considering the impact it has on strategic decision-making?  

", "Interviewee: Oh, sure. That's a very important piece. Um, uh, I used to tell it to my team. It's like garbage in, garbage out. So if we are making decision based on the these data so these data output or on the insight comes from the input we give it to, uh, the machine. So the system doesn't have their own intelligences as of now if we talk about. So, um, I used to talk to my team that whenever we put any data, we have to be really accurate about it. Like, uh, for that matter, I'll give you an example. Like, sometimes what happens is, like, a hiring manager say that, okay. I'm keeping this, um, like, requirement on hold for some time. And if the TA person doesn't go and change that into the system, that, okay, it is on hold for now. The aging will keep on going. Right? So, um, that will reflect the wrong data about that rule that, okay, this rule is open for this long, while in actual, it was on hold. So, uh, to make sure that whatever data is going into the system is accurate and correct is important aspect of it. And that, um, goes without saying that each and every member of the TA team takes care of it and be very vigilant about it and be very active on it. Um, so that's how I took care of this piece.

"], ['Interviewer: Absolutely, the "garbage in, garbage out" principle is crucial in data management. Shifting focus a bit, you mentioned leading a global talent acquisition team with positions ranging from 90 to 300 open roles. Could you discuss a specific challenge you faced in managing such a large-scale operation and the strategies you implemented to address it, particularly from a stakeholder management perspective?  

', "Interviewee: Sure. Um, stakeholder management piece is one important or strong point of me, I would say, in my role. Um, I give very, uh, important, uh, like, due weighted latest to communication. Communication is the key piece in stakeholder management. And, uh, what all it can do best. So right from the kickoff meeting, when you meet the hiring team for the first time, so you set, uh, everything at at place. Like, you know, you start with your, um, SLAs first that okay. These these these are my SLAs, and my recruiting team will take care of it. But at the same time, uh, recruiting is a partnership. Okay? So it's not that just the hiring. The recruiting team, uh, will do all part. We need equal support from the hiring team, the hiring managers, the interviewers. So, um, setting the stage up, setting expectations up, like, you know, following the industry standards of feedback sharing, like, within 24 hours, uh, the feedback should be in the system. And then, um, if if we have scheduled an interview and you're not able to make it, um, after accepting the invite, so it's your duty to, uh, give give your, you know, your replacement at that time so that we can take care of the candidate experience part. Apart from, you know, doing the kickoff meeting and, um, bringing everybody at, um, uh, at same, uh, ground, the expectation setting in SLAs. Um, then the approach which I take is a 3 stage approach. Like, first, I believe in listening very clearly with open ears and, um, understanding their pain areas, what exactly they want, what are the their main concern areas. Um, the second stage comes where, um, I share my research, my knowledge with them, and understanding of the candidate landscape and the candidate market, how it looks like, and share with the hiring manager and set up that trust that, yes, we know our bit, and, um, this is the insights. This is the, um, current, um, talent mapping, which um, we know and share with them. So the trust is where they know and they understand that, okay, we are coming with, uh, some background, some research, some knowledge. Then the 3rd stage come where, you know, we execute stuff and then we hear each other, like, if we are, um, not satisfying them. So we hear, um, our feedback constructively and try and improve on that side. Same way when you build that trust and, um, cater to that, then they also are ready to hear what you have to say. Like, you know, sometimes what happens is, like, they're looking for a star, a player and keep running towards that and, um, not understanding that maybe that skill mix is not not, um, that, um, abundance in the market. So, um, this is the piece which, uh, helps me in stakeholder management. Then 4th part comes is is is the data sharing. Like, you know, when you share the data with the hiring manager that, okay, we have reviewed these many profiles. Out of them, we'd screened out these many candidate, and then we just are sharing these, you know, fully filtered candidate to them. So making them aware of the process also that, um, what due diligence we are doing from our part, then they are more, um, you know, accepting and, um, understanding. So that also helps in stakeholder management. And, yeah, I guess this is all.

"], ['Interviewer: Your three-stage approach to stakeholder engagement, starting with listening and moving to knowledge sharing and execution, is quite insightful. How do you ensure this level of engagement and process adherence across different teams, especially in a geographically dispersed setup like North America and APAC?  

', "Interviewee: Yeah. Good question. Um, so when you set an approach and process, uh, it's always important that you do the consistency and, um, cater to everybody equally. And for that, um, I I I I believe in empowering my team. So it should not be that I'm the bottleneck, and I always do all bits and piece of it. So, um, as I said that I was managing the global team, um, sitting in North America and India, who was managing APAC. And North America, the team sitting in California, Campbell, was managing North America. So I used to empower my team, um, impart all the knowledge and all the approach with them, and keep them trained and, uh, mentored around it. And, um, I I created different swim lanes for different recruiters that, okay, this department, uh, you will be handled. So these are your stakeholders. And, um, so their level would be till director level. And if there, um, my, uh, if there is any escalation. So I, um, used to come into the picture. So I I I did this management incrementally, you can say, and keep on, um, believe in continuous improvement and continuous, um, empowering of the team and, uh, continuous um, mentoring of the team, um, where, uh, you set, um, KPIs for them very clearly that these are your KPIs. Stakeholder management is also a piece. Um, and, um, accordingly, they understand that it's not about just the execution that, okay, a hiring has come and then you have to just fill that with numbers. No. The quality matters, and, um, that will increase your stakeholder management. So so, um, keeping that, you know, regular in your team helps in managing it across the, um, across different reason, across different time zone. And I am one person which don't believe in, um, um, holding up anything. Like, if anything is pending on me, I'm the blocker. I would, um, do it right away. And I used to make myself available, uh, in different time zone as well. Like, you know, I used to be up in ISTRs as well even being in Vancouver, because I really like recruiting function, and I can't hold things up, um, just on me and, uh, keep the whole process hanging. So that helped me.

"], ['Interviewer: Empowering your team and establishing clear swim lanes for responsibility is a strong management approach. Shifting focus to the technical side, you mentioned implementing ATS systems, particularly Lever. What were some of the key technical challenges you faced during the implementation of Lever, and how did you overcome them to ensure a smooth transition for your team?  

', "Interviewee: Nice questions. So, um, technical as in, um, as I'm into recruiting functions, it was not like, uh, any tech part I did for the implementation. So the tech implementation was done. I would say that what part I worked for was the acceptance of it. You know? Because change is one thing which is not welcome for, uh, welcome all the time. Okay? Like, especially for hiring managers and interviewers. So they're already busy with their core work. Right? Their core work was their function. And when you change thing, it is a overburden, overhead for them. Right? So, um, making them understand the value of it that, okay, right now we are spending some time on it, but, uh, in long run, it will save immense time of them. Right? Because everything doing over email and losing tracks of it and, um, that, uh, waste a lot of time for everybody. And having an ATS, um, so making them understand the value of it that everything will be at one place. In one click, you can see different things. It will give you different insights about your team, about, um, the work, about how many team members are taking, how many interviews. So you will have a good assessment of your contribution in hiring and your team members' contribution in hiring. So I would say the, again, uh, the management piece of, uh, uh, of acceptance of the new ATS, uh, which I worked. And then, uh, definitely, on technical side, I would say that, um, I created different forms like feedback form. So I created a, um, feedback form, um, in the system, and then I gave a presentation come training to the interviewing and hiring team to tell them, like, how it is working. Like, I used that, um, scale of 1 to 5 for ratings. So what means what? Like, one means least and 5 means more. So, um, sharing them about it and where they can, um, apart from rating, how where they can give the detailed feedback. So introducing them to the different fields and how to navigate, um, across the ATS, um, for the info they need. Um, so that part I took care of during the implementation.

"], ['Interviewer: Focusing on the change management aspect of the ATS implementation is crucial, especially in a field where technical adoption might face resistance. How do you envision leveraging more advanced technologies, such as AI and machine learning, within the recruitment process to further enhance efficiency and effectiveness, and what challenges do you anticipate in adopting these technologies in a talent acquisition context?  

', "Interviewee: Wow. So, um, AI, ML, these things are future. Right? Every industry is is embracing it, and recruiting function has to embrace it if, uh, we want to be, um, you know, seen as a valued partner, um, with different functions. Right? So, um, I have seen different, um, tools like, uh, MetaView Notetaker, um, um, then this platform where I'm currently giving interviews. So that seems quite useful and, um, time saving. Um, so I definitely welcome these, uh, tools, these, uh, interventions and recruiting function, and I see that it will be only helpful. The challenge part is that, um, this function deals with human. Right? And we should not lose the human touch and, um, and that feel. So there always should be some personalization, but, um, using, um, AI and ML will be beneficial. The only trick point is striking a good balance that, you know, you can have best of both the world. That empathy, that human touch, um, and along with the technology, um, will make us grow in leaps and bounds. So, yeah, that's my view around it.

"], ["Interviewer: Finding the balance between technological efficiency and human touch is indeed a critical point, especially in a field as people-centric as recruitment. In terms of the tools and platforms you've mentioned, like Metaview and note-taker, how do you evaluate the effectiveness of these AI-driven solutions in terms of their impact on your key metrics, such as time to hire, quality of hire, and candidate experience?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. So if I talk about Metaview notetaker, um, that's definitely a good, um, I would say, tool for both the part you you mentioned, like candidate experience and efficiency and quality. Because, see, uh, what meter view, uh, note taker does is they'll take notes, uh, of the interview and then send it to the interviewer. So many a time what happens that they hear from, um, the interviewers that, okay. I don't have time to give feedback, and I'll do it later. And then when they go on go back on, um, um, later and then they start writing feedback there, they have, you know, lost maybe critical part of the interview, uh, and then discussion. So having met of your notetaker, uh, in the picture, they'll have they can, you know, they can review the notes. They can refresh their memories by filling the feedback. That will increase the quality of hire. Right? Because when the correct feedback goes into the system, um, then the decision will be better. So that helps how, um, the note taking and efficiency, um, like, you know, uh, you do not to worry or bother about writing those notes, and the system is doing it for you. So you are a 100% into the conversation, and you are more involved. So, again, giving a good, um, candidate, uh, experience because, um, they will also feel that, yes, you are not just a machine taking notes, but you are actually involved in the conversation. Right? So it definitely help in efficiency, quality of hire, and then, uh, candidate experience because, um, candidate also feels, uh, much engaged, informed, and they have necessary tool, uh, for the interview.

"], ['Interviewer: The use of Metaview Note Taker to enhance both the interview process and candidate experience is a strategic application of AI to achieve multiple goals simultaneously. As you look to integrate more of these AI-driven solutions, what criteria do you use to select which tools to adopt, and how do you ensure they align with your overarching recruitment strategy?  

', 'Interviewee: Okay. Um, I would say the cost, uh, plays an important, um, role here that and and the scaling as well. Like, if you are, uh, so every company has different challenges and different, um, and they are at a different stage in that company life cycle. You know? So, um, it is, uh, quite dependent on, um, the company. So if your company is, um, at some scale, so you have to evaluate, um, ask for them that, you know, the cost involved, what return on investment ROI you are getting out of it. And you will have to measure that quality of hire, the efficiency, the, um, the, um, the candidate experience, um, to to cater for that. Like, okay, you can do, say, a test run and, um, meaning companies do provide demos and, um, uh, test subscriptions for these AI tools. So use that tool, evaluate your, um, matrix around it, and how it held it. Does it really change? And what percent does it change? The the the impact it is having, is it, um, you know, um, good enough to invest that amount? So that will be the approach, you know, cost versus ROI.

'], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}
candidateBTranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview?
', 'Interviewee: Yeah. Yes.
'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've had extensive experience in end-to-end recruitment, particularly in the finance and customer support sectors. Can you walk me through a challenging recruitment project you managed and how you utilized your stakeholder management skills to ensure its success?  
", "Interviewee: Yeah. Sure. So I have filled more than 400 positions for clients like Arrow, EY, uh, Jensen Hughes, and IDD CPC. I was mainly recruiting. As I said, it was for customer service and finance. So we had, uh, approximately 50 to 60, uh, target per month. And sometimes we had the bulk hiring for which we used to, uh, which was very challenging for us. So I usually made sure that I had the pipeline ready. So for that, I used to initiate the sourcing process beforehand and maintain a pipeline of the talent pool so that we don't have any shortage of the profiles so that we can complete all the targets that we get monthly.
"], ["Interviewer: That's quite an impressive volume of positions to fill. Maintaining a talent pipeline is crucial for such high-volume hiring. Can you tell me more about how you engaged with stakeholders, both internal and external, to ensure that the hiring process was efficient and that the quality of hires met the client's expectations?  
", "Interviewee: Yeah. Sure. So, internally, we, uh, actually, I with and my manager and my whole team had this meeting in the morning and where we decided how we are going to, uh, complete it throughout the day. And internally, we, uh, set we used to set the target. And with the external stakeholders, uh, I usually, uh, used to maintain the hiring data, which I used to update the on a daily basis. And once or twice in the week, I used to update them with the hiring data on the call. So all the stakeholders were really updated on whatever is going on, uh, with the candidate pipeline and how many we have recruited, how many are in the process, and how many are offered. So that's how we managed everything, and, uh, we had 1 on on 1 on 1, uh, you know, calls with the stakeholders and clients to make sure that they are also updated on the same.
"], ['Interviewer: It sounds like you had a very structured approach to communication and data management. Given your proficiency in Excel, can you describe a specific instance where you used advanced features of Excel to analyze hiring data or to create reports that helped in decision-making for the recruitment process?  
', 'Interviewee: Yes. So we usually, uh, like, I have used Excel only to make the reports, and we had multiple clients. Like I said, I used to manage Arrow, uh, Jensen Hughes, and ITD CPC. And before that, when I was hiring for customer service as well, I was, uh, working with Honeywell and other clients. So, uh, 2 Excel reports, I used to make the report where it was clearly mentioned that for the month, how much we have achieved our target, how much can how many candidates are offered, how many are still in the progress. And so that that made actually a clear report and they were clear on the numbers that how many we are expecting in the next month or the coming months. So we have the pipeline there as well. So on that basis, they were also able to, uh, you know, give us the numbers that how many numbers we have to complete, we have to, uh, meet the target. And they were also, uh, you know, uh, content on the fact that how many numbers we have already completed. So that was a report that really helped us to make the decisions on that.
'], ["Interviewer: That's a great use of Excel for tracking and reporting on key metrics. Now, considering your experience with offline recruitment drives, how did you ensure that the candidates you met at these events were effectively tracked and managed in your candidate pipeline, and how did you integrate this data with your existing online recruitment processes?  
", "Interviewee: So as, uh, through clients, we're getting the numbers. Like, how many numbers we'll be getting? How many what are the requirements for the particular process? Like, uh, in, if I talk about finance, it was g l a p a r and different, uh, you know, process for which I was hiring. So for each process, for APAR, GL, for customer, for CS as well, uh, we were getting the numbers that these are the particular, uh, requirement that we have to fulfill. So we were also sourcing online, uh, through our direct team through, uh, Nokri, and we will also had our vendors. So we will also, uh, connecting with vendors on 1 on 1, and they were helping us, uh, in sending the profiles online. So we are we were getting the list beforehand, uh, you know, before the offline recruitments that we had, um, in our offices. So before that, we got the list of the candidates and they were, uh, online. They were they were invited for the offline office recruitment rights. So, uh, that was the, uh, thing that we used to manage the offline recruitment drives. And when we met the candidates, we made sure that the screening process, uh, is done smoothly. And there only we did that test screening process shortlisting, and we, uh, schedule the interviews as well. And they have when they did the interviews, then we ask the candidates to, uh, uh, come to the office next day or we'll update them online. So they were updated online through the mails, whether they are selected or not.
"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you've developed a comprehensive strategy for integrating offline and online recruitment efforts. Given your experience with vendor management, can you discuss how you evaluated and selected vendors to ensure they provided high-quality candidates, and what metrics or KPIs you used to measure the performance of these vendors in the recruitment process?  
", 'Interviewee: Sure. So, uh, like, we had dedicated vendors for each process. Like, uh, we had dedicated vendor for CS, for customer service, for voice process, small voice process, and also for the finance, like accounts payable, accounts receivable, general ledger. All these profiles, we had different vendors which were dedicated to these particular profiles. So, uh, we used to connect with them 1 on 1 on the call, and they used to provide us the list. And we also used to update them that what are the candidate pipeline that we are not using anymore or the candidates that are not selected. So we used to, um, remove that from the list, and we updated them regarding that. And whenever we had the requirement, we asked them to, uh, send us the list, whatever they had. And within 1 or 2 days, they used to send the list of candidates. They sourced really well. And once we get the we got the candidates, we used to screen them, should do the interviews, after interviews. We updated them regarding their selection. Yep.
'], ["Interviewer: It's great to hear that you had a structured approach to vendor management, with dedicated vendors for specific profiles and regular communication to ensure the quality of the candidate pipeline. Can you tell me about a time when you had to address a performance issue with a vendor and how you managed to resolve it while maintaining a positive working relationship?  
", "Interviewee: So, uh, yeah. As I said, there were many vendors which are dedicated to a particular profiles, and we were handling multiple profiles for multiple processes. So there was a time when we had the bulk requirement, and a lot of update was also required. So, uh, we used to have this meeting, uh, where we connected with all the vendors. And in one go, we we used to update them regarding the candidates so that they'll, uh, just update them in their report or in their Excel sheet, and that will reduce the confusion that we had while updating and, like, creating a lot of calls 1 on 1 with different vendors. Instead of that, when we had bulk hiring, we used to connect with all the vendors at once, and we updated them regarding the position of the candidates.
"], ["Interviewer: That's a strategic approach to vendor management, especially during high-volume hiring periods. By consolidating updates in a group setting, you not only streamlined communication but also ensured that all vendors were on the same page. Can you discuss how you monitored the performance of these vendors after implementing this group update strategy, and what specific improvements or changes you tracked to ensure the vendor's performance met your expectations?  
", "Interviewee: So, yeah, uh, there was a lot of times when when we had the these candidates from the vendors, which were very difficult candidates. Like, we can say, like, uh, after all after the whole process, like the sourcing, screening, getting the candidates, um, document verification, interview schedule after all that. Even the when the candidate is selected and even when the open negotiation has been done, even after that, a few candidates were not responding or there will be candidates who were troublesome. So we used to, uh, you know, communicate this with the vendors. I used to communicate it with the vendor on the call. And even on through the mails, I used to update them that, uh, please don't provide such, uh, candidates or such profiles, which are so troublesome that, uh, we, uh, spent our whole month, you know, interviewing, screening them, shortlisting them, doing document verification, releasing offers, and then we are not hearing from this. Those this was a challenge that we were facing and we are facing with the vendors. But I we made them clear through the mails that what are the problems that we are facing. So they were also focused on the profiles that the kind of profiles that the company is looking for. So they were all sending only those profiles which were appropriate for the company and which will not waste the time of the company anymore.
"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you've taken a proactive approach to vendor performance by providing detailed feedback on candidate quality and responsiveness. This level of communication is essential for maintaining high standards in the recruitment process. Can you tell me about a specific instance where your feedback led to a significant improvement in the quality of candidates provided by a vendor, and how you measured this improvement?  
", "Interviewee: I assure. So, uh, uh, there was a time when we have when I was getting a lot of candidates who were really troublesome. So I updated all the vendors where where we get into such candidates. So I updated them, and they were also interested in knowing that what what are the kind of candidates candidates that we are not interested in. So, yeah, we had a call also where we updated them that these are the kind of candidates which are causing trouble, which are wasting the company's time. So we are not looking for such candidates. And also the candidates with more than 3 months of notice. Because 2 or 3 months of notice period, they were also troublesome because, uh, they were, uh, you know, having offer in hand or something like that, which was causing, uh, no delay in the hiring targets achieving the hiring targets. So that was the reason, uh, how, uh, why we communicated this with the vendors. And then when vendors also improved their candidate pipeline, they also focused on the candidates with, uh, more or less than 15 days or 1 month on notice period or or the candidates who are, uh, immediate joiners because we had the bulk hiring and the necessity of the profiles at that moment urgently. So that's how vendors also understood and provided us better candidates after that.
"], ["Interviewer: That's a great example of how targeted feedback can lead to better outcomes. By specifying the desired notice periods and candidate responsiveness, you were able to influence the quality of the candidates being submitted. How did you track the change in the notice periods and responsiveness of the candidates provided by the vendors? Did you use any specific metrics or reports to measure the impact of this feedback on the recruitment process?  
", 'Interviewee: Yeah. Like, after this communication with the with the vendors, we used to get the candidates. We focus on the candidates with less than 1 month of notice period or the immediate joiners. So what happened, uh, that after this, because the candidates were immediate joiners, we were able to achieve our targets, uh, early. Like, uh, like, even if we are having 40 to 50 targets, with the immediate joiners, we were uh, able to get 30 to 40 targets per month. So that was the reason, uh, why we communicated this with the vendors. And due to the improvement of the candidate pipeline and due to the improvement of the candidate profile and and the candidates who are serious, who are active, who are responsive, Because of that, we, uh, were we were able to achieve our targets, and we were also able to, uh, you know, provide, uh, good candidates to our clients.
'], ["Interviewer: Achieving such significant improvements in target fulfillment is commendable. It's clear that your feedback had a direct impact on the efficiency of the recruitment process. In terms of candidate quality, how did you ensure that the candidates with shorter notice periods or immediate availability still met the necessary skill and experience requirements for the positions, and what methods did you use to verify this before presenting them to the hiring managers?  
", "Interviewee: So, uh, once we had the candidate pipeline of the candidates with less than, uh, one one month of notice period or who were immediate joiners, We used to do the proper screening. Sometimes we did online. Sometimes we did offline in the recruitment during the recruitment drive at our office at Infosys. So, uh, we were having this proper screening process where we made sure that all the highlighting, uh, you know, requirements of the jobs are met before we send those candidates for the in, uh, job interview. So once they, uh, pass their screening process and once we made sure that they had all the documents that were necessary, uh, for the process, then we, uh, schedule the interview with the with our managers, and they took the interviews. And after properly assessing their, uh, you know, uh, their skills. Only after that, they proceeded with the selection process. And after the background checks, document verification, we had this one on one call with them, offer negotiation with them, where we made sure that they were okay with the offer that we are providing from our company. So once everything was set, only then we proceeded with the onboarding and process offer release process. So that's how we made sure that the candidate has all the skills that are required for the job that he has to perform.
"], ['Interviewer: Your approach to screening and ensuring candidates meet the job requirements is thorough and essential for maintaining quality in the hiring process. Given your experience with both online and offline screening, can you share how you adapted your screening process to ensure consistency and fairness for candidates, regardless of whether they were screened online or in person at a recruitment drive?  
', "Interviewee: So, uh, because all the candidates that we had, you were receiving either from our, uh, direct sourcing team or through the Naukri profiles or through the vendors. So we were collecting the profiles from all the sources that were available to us and from all the sources that we could source from. And after that, we had this phone screening first where we used to screen all the candidates, uh, no matter what the source is from where the candidates, uh, we have selected from. So, uh, we used to do the phone screening first where we make sure the candidate is responding responsive. We had this response from the candidate. He's active. He's sending his documents, and, uh, he's available to join within the required time and everything after only after that, we did the proper screening face to face screening, it was. And we used to do that, uh, uh, online as well as offline. So most of the time after COVID, we used to start, uh, doing it offline only so that we have this conversation face to face with the candidates where we can properly, uh, you know, connect with them and properly understand their, uh, you know, their communication skills, their other skills that are required for the job. So, uh, yeah, we make sure that the screening is done. Before COVID, we make sure that it was done online and it is done properly on the phone as well as on a video call. And even if it was after COVID during the, uh, during our 2 pill drives at office or anything like that. We also made sure that we are the screening is going as, uh, same as we're doing it online. So there was no difference online or or offline because we are we were doing it face to face.
"], ["Interviewer: Maintaining consistency in the screening process, whether it's conducted online or in person, is crucial for fair candidate evaluation. Given your experience with both methods, how do you ensure that the criteria for evaluating communication skills and other job-relevant competencies remain consistent across different modes of screening, such as phone, video, and in-person interviews?  
", 'Interviewee: So, uh, like, uh, at Infosys, I used to there was a process for all the, uh, you know, profiles that we were hiring for. Like, for finance, like, apart from c s, c s, we were only doing the phone screening and the video screening, offline screening after that in scheduling interviews and documentation, everything. But for finance, we also have the test. So for different, uh, profiles had different processes that were that involved that was involved. So we used to take the test first. Once the candidate passes the passes the test, only after that the screening was done. So at that point, only for the finance profiles, we make sure that, uh, the candidates already had the knowledge and skills that are required for the job. And after that, we used to, uh, communicate with the candidate to understand, uh, the skills of the candidates in person. And after that, we after the screening is done and they are shortlisted, I used to send them for the in, uh, interview schedule. So once the interview was done and once the candidate was selected, we went for the document verification and background check and offer negotiation and offer release. So that was the process. So the test which, uh, showed that all the skills and knowledge is already, uh, you know, the the candidate is capable of doing that. Capable the candidate has a capability of the skills. Candidate has all the knowledge that is required for that particular job.
'], ["Interviewer: Implementing a test as part of the screening process for finance profiles is a solid strategy to ensure candidates have the necessary technical skills. When you're evaluating these tests, how do you standardize the scoring or assessment to ensure fairness across all candidates? Additionally, how do you handle situations where a candidate may perform exceptionally well on the test but doesn't demonstrate the same level of competence during the in-person or video interview?  
", "Interviewee: Yeah, sure. So during the test. There was a criteria that the candidates had to meet. Like it was something I think 60% was there which carried was you know supposed to pass. So once the candidate has cleared the test and it was same for everyone. So on the test basis a lot of candidates were selected for the you know, move forward for the screening process. And once we had the candidates who have cleared the tests mostly what happened the candidates were cleared the test working capable of you know, clearing the screening process also, but only few of them who are for voice profiles supposed that they're having this voice profile for years or something and even for finance they were some of the candidates some of the profiles which were voice process not for non-voice. So for voice process, it was in a very necessary for us that we checked the communication skill of the candidate. And for that abuse to do the screening and even if the candidate has the technical skill, but the communication is not well, he's not able to communicate his knowledge communicate his ideas Thoughts with the managers. So they were not selected up to that process because in that particular job, it was very necessary the candidate because candidate has to speak a lot communicate with people a lot and tell them regarding that process. So if the candidate is was not able to communicate. Well, we didn't, you know proceeded with the other processes and the candidate was not selected any further. Even if the candidate has a cleared the test. Yeah.
"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview!
