'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've worked extensively on brand communication and content strategy development. Can you walk me through a specific example of how you tailored messaging for a startup client, and what key factors you considered in that process?  

", 'Interviewee: I worked for a startup called Peacefully, which helps individuals work through end of life necessities and

'], ['Interviewer: That sounds like a challenging but important project. How did you approach the tone and style of the messaging for Peacefully, considering the sensitive nature of the services they provide?  

', "Interviewee: Yeah. That was a that's a great question. And I, uh, what we did was we focused on being we looked around, first of all, competitors and saw how, uh, the other businesses that were in the same space spoke because, uh, one way that we recognize to stand out was have distinction in our brand voice. And we recognized that there was, uh, a lot of coldness in their tone. So we really worked on being as empathetic as possible, especially as you mentioned given the sensitive nature of the work. And so we looked at every communication on Instagram, etcetera, and made sure that it sounded like a human being, and that it also sounded like it was, um, even though we were providing necessary information, it was put in such a way that it was considered of where a person may be in their life in terms of potentially having just experienced a loss.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you put a lot of thought into that process. How did you measure the effectiveness of this new brand voice and messaging approach, particularly in terms of user engagement or feedback?  

", 'Interviewee: Yeah. We primarily looked at reviews and actually we interfaced a lot with our, uh, with our client base because, essentially, we were pretty small and we and the first couple people who are using the platform were, um, were essentially the first. So we were able to communicate directly with them. Some of them we actually knew personally. And we got a lot of important feedback about how the flow of information and questions was designed. Uh, we and we we, uh, of course, we were cautious of the fact that the sample size was not huge and but we did insist that people were unsparing in their criticism and then we factored in their feedback. And as time went on and we got more and more feedback, we were then able to test the changes that we were making against, uh, how people were feeling about the content.

'], ["Interviewer: That's a very hands-on and user-centric approach to feedback. Shifting focus a bit, I'd like to discuss your experience with SEO best practices. Can you describe a particularly challenging SEO problem you encountered at White Glove Financial and how you solved it?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Our goal at White Glove Financial was to write new content that would live inside of a platform and, uh, that we had built. And, uh, actually, we had acquired it. We had acquired it from another company, but then we were refining it for our needs. Uh, the company was, uh, the the goal of the company was for financial advisors to stay in touch with clients and recruit new business. And, uh, one of the ways to do that is basically to be introducing topics to people that were, um, that were sufficiently interesting and but would also lead to the conclusion that they could not master the subject themselves. They had to speak to a financial adviser. So what we did was we would have content that lived on our own platform, but we would share it on social media. And I would say the challenge with Facebook social media is, first of all, just from a back end standpoint, they are skeptical of platforms like ours, so we really had to be rigorous in conforming to their, um, their proprietary standards, um, because if you were too boring, uh, in your in any aspect of your content, it would not share that content widely, and it was really working against what we were trying to do for those financial advisors. So suffice to say that that that course that position required a crash course in Facebook SEO in particular, uh, now Meta, but we weren't really primarily using Instagram as much as we were trying to use Facebook because we recognized that that was more in line with where the customer base primarily was interacting on social media.

"], ["Interviewer: It's interesting how you tailored the content to not only be engaging but also to drive a specific action. Given the challenges with Facebook's algorithm and standards, can you elaborate on some of the specific strategies or techniques you found most effective in ensuring your content was both engaging and compliant with their standards?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. I would say the way to do that within Facebook is that you're essentially just answering line by line as you probably know, um, both, uh, a subject title and then an article title. And so what you would do was, of course, you'd have the article title be something that would be outward facing and engaging. But then sort of the subject title would be, uh, basically a keyword rich thing that Facebook would recognize, um, as something that should be shared widely if someone was, uh, the type of person who was reading, for example, a lot of financial information on Facebook or even the Wall Street Journal, for example, we recognize. Those are the types of people who, um, were, you know, a big part of our demographic. Because the whole point of the financial advisor situation is that you are trying to get people to realize they don't know enough about a subject. And on that end, ultimately, um, while the content was while the goal of the content was this was definitely to be clear, It was also to emphasize the many pitfalls of trying to manage financial, uh, advice and, uh, management of one's portfolio by oneself. So the the goal was definitely not to be, um, muddy, but it was essentially to communicate the the the the crucial importance of getting these decisions right and how also how much of a relief it is when those decisions have been outsourced to someone who is ostensibly a professional because essentially, the financial advisor's pitch is that you don't, um, you know, you don't get get into a limousine with someone who's never driven before, and if you've never driven before yourself, you don't just get behind the wheel of a car and start driving. Um, and and ultimately that, um, while on a surface level, financial decisions are simple from the standpoint of just investing in index funds has has been the operative wisdom for 20 to 30 years. There are also so many decisions underneath, uh, retirement investing. For example, um, management of one's home and estate, education saving and spending, etcetera, um, and then the tax implications of all that that one should be thinking about. And and the goal was to emphasize how a holistic approach like that is so much more advantageous than just thinking, oh, I'm gonna buy um, whatever index fund at a regular price and blah blah blah, and that's all I need to do to be in a good situation financially.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to content framing and targeting is quite strategic. Shifting back to the technical side, could you explain how you approached the technical aspects of SEO, such as on-page optimization or site structure, to ensure the content you were creating for the financial advisors' platform was not only engaging but also highly discoverable by search engines?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. Although I think I've kind of done that a few times, but I I guess basically, uh, when you're working, uh, in the back end in meta and you are it it in some part, this was a collaboration with with the, uh, people who had built the platform that we were then using at White Glove, which was, um, which, as I said, was proprietary, but would also allow financial advisors to not only share content via social media, but also keep track of their clients and prospects. It was basically one big dashboard. So, uh, but that the some of the decisions about how to optimize, uh, and get plugged in directly to Facebook and what they needed were being handled by the back end developing people who, uh, who were a separate team, and I was not necessarily a part of that team. They did ask me what what they would love to from me would and I was very simple in my response, which is just, hey. We need, um, we need stuff that looks professional, and we need stuff that looks like it's coming from the Wall Street Journal and other, uh, outlets that people trust because we just don't wanna look like, well, a very bad version of NerdWallet, for example. Um, so but but I will say that, uh, the most of the decisions for how to optimize, um, from a digital standpoint were, uh, were being handled by the back end development team because the goal was not to go viral on Facebook necessarily. The goal was to be much more, uh, personal and and informative and not really trying for fireworks, but really trying to simply just look professional and those that required, um, just building a system that talked to Facebook and answered all the questions and and looked like it was a professional outlet.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you had a strong focus on the user experience and the credibility of the content. Given your role in ensuring the content's professionalism and trustworthiness, how did you collaborate with the development team to maintain a balance between the visual and functional aspects of the platform, especially in terms of SEO considerations?  

", "Interviewee: Well, the platform was I there's a little bit of a lack of overlap here because the SEO considerations were, um, you know, but they were basically internally handled. And then when it came but when it came to actually, uh, the design of the of the interface itself, um, that it was important that financial advisers would have an easy time navigating that because those were our direct clients. Uh, we weren't dealing with people who were trying to reach financial advisers. We were dealing with financial advisers and and those people can be quite conservative in in their approach. So I would say the the abundance of focus was placed on simply having an easy to use professional looking sort of Charles Schwabbe type interface that, uh, the type of people who were our direct clients, which as I mentioned, were very conservative, basically mid market and small market financial professionals who were just trying to grow their business from 5 to 7 to 9 to 13. Uh, they could be sharing content on Facebook that was not just, hey, I'm a financial advisor, come talk to me, but was professional looking, um, and also, um, and also content that they could trust and that and that emphasize the right content goals, which is let's just get people in the door and start having a conversation regardless of where they're at in life, and especially if they're at a turning point in life, like getting their first job, getting married, etcetera.

"], ["Interviewer: It's interesting to see how the focus on user experience and trustworthiness extended to the platform's design and functionality. Given the conservative nature of the target audience, how did you approach the content strategy to ensure it resonated with financial advisors and helped them achieve their business growth goals?  

", "Interviewee: That's a great question. It was definitely something that we handled using, um, what what was happening at White Glove while I was there was we were leasing a a content platform, uh, that was widely used, um, and that we were paying a lot of money for, but that allowed advisers to share paywalled content, which was kind of the, uh, opportunity benefit that was being promoted to financial advisers and consequently to their clients, the type of people who, um, basically the incentive would be I'm gonna follow financial advisor x on Facebook because by doing so, I'll be able to read stuff on Forbes and Barron's, etcetera, uh, financial outlets that pay well their content. Bloomberg would be another example. Um, and we were getting away from that. We were we were having to do it ourselves. And so, um, so we we actually had an opportunity to spend 3 or 4 months surveying our current client base of financial advisors and asking them the type of content that they think would be good for their audience. Now we also recognize that they wouldn't necessarily be the best judges of that. Um, for example, uh, we got a lot of feedback about not including or even bothering to write anything about cryptocurrency. That's, you know, that's it was a type of thing that, um, that financial advisers were tired of hearing about, but at the same time, from a from a conversion standpoint in terms of bringing in new clients, it tested extremely highly after the fact for being the type of thing that that people were actually coming in the door and talking about. And that became particularly true as time went on and as we have now reached the point where there are Bitcoin ETFs and soon to be ether ETFs. This is the type of thing that, um, that at least the younger client base of financial advisers work with are definitely interested in diversifying their portfolio and especially given the state of the market right now, uh, in terms of being at an all time high. So, um, so to some degree, we were able to, uh, modulate and control the type of content that financial advisers would see and particularly the stuff that they wouldn't see, but it was also part of my job and our role as a company to convince them that the topics like LGBTQ would be another example that they might consider to be, um, outside of their purview and also potentially politically hazardous are also exactly the kind of things that a, get interest from people, and, b, may potentially grow a client base because, of course, with the younger generation, there are also more gay couples and things like that, and it's and it's financial advisers. Uh, once they use the platform would recognize that if they shared content about that, they could control who got to see it, um, and and and also who didn't get to see it so that they could be less conservative in their approach.

"], ["Interviewer: It's fascinating to see how you navigated the balance between the financial advisors' preferences and the actual audience engagement data. Given the success of introducing topics like cryptocurrency and LGBTQ finance, how did you measure the impact of these new content areas on the financial advisors' client acquisition and retention?  

", "Interviewee: That was just something that we would reach out, uh, after 6 months, uh, of being on the platform. Actually, we did a small survey at 3 months and then a bigger one at 6 months. And, uh, in addition to the daily feedback that we would be getting through private channels, things like emails and chat, etcetera, that we were, uh, that we were keeping in contact with financial advisers. But we also did a concerted survey to see how these people were feeling about their content. And then, um, and, of course, also ask them to rate the effectiveness of certain content. There were also it's was not a huge client base of financial advisors, so it was the type of people that our account team regularly interface with. And I would say it was a priority of mine to, um, to route as many of those calls over to me as possible and or to be interacting with, uh, the 2 women who were in charge of the account base to hear the anecdotes about how certain content was performing and others not. Um, you know, the the there was never it was never surprised that backdoor Roth conversions were of interest to people, but, uh, it was it was, um, heartening to hear that, uh, social issues were driving as much of the conversation.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you had a comprehensive approach to gathering feedback and measuring the impact of the content strategy. Given the success of this approach, how did you use these insights to further refine the content strategy and potentially explore new areas of focus for the financial advisors' platform?  

", "Interviewee: Well, I think you just answered the question. We we I would say it's not easy to say how we did that. Uh, that's just what we did. I mean, we we would, um, we would continue to write about basic issues, but, um, I think we recognize that what is a Roth IRA was not the kind of thing that would get the same feedback as something that was a little more incendiary, especially given that we were using social media. So I would say, um, I actually think from the beginning, we bit off a lot of of, uh, news verticals and

"], ['Interviewer: It sounds like you were able to identify and leverage the power of engaging and sometimes controversial topics to drive engagement and conversation. Given this shift in strategy, how did you ensure that the content remained informative and valuable to the audience, even when discussing more incendiary topics?  

', "Interviewee: Well, I wouldn't say we ever got 2 incendiary, but I would say that, uh, we we worked closely with a, uh, with a company that, um, uh, hired writers on someone's behalf when you were in charge of a team, and they turned out the the you were able to work with the same writer. You didn't get new ones all the time, so we were able to basically say, oh, this is our financial expert and they really get, uh, how we're writing, uh, how we're trying to write in a certain quasi journalistic tone, but but mostly on the informative side of things. And and then when we threw that person, um, a maybe more incendiary topic, and I don't think we ever did anything too incendiary, they knew to write it in our kind of brand voice because that was what that company in particular specialized in. And then I was there as a final judge of whether, uh, the content was adhering to our copy and voice guidelines.

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}
candidateBTranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Yes.

'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've worked on a variety of television and film projects, including the World of Warcraft animated series. Can you walk me through the process of developing a concept for a new series, from the initial idea to the pitch stage?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. So you start out, with a concept. Usually, it's a theme. From there, you move on to, coming up with some characters. And you place those characters in a world. And with World of Warcraft, you had a world that already existed, so you could start with using all of the Warcraft races, characters and, sides and factions, to help create the whole process. And then once you sort of have these characters working, you can come then sort of come up with the, the mission of the show and then you create your pitch deck and you pitch it.

"], ["Interviewer: That's a comprehensive overview. When it comes to character development, how do you ensure that the characters are not only compelling but also fit within the established lore of a franchise like World of Warcraft?  

", "Interviewee: You work with people who are very aware of the, and familiar with the, the brand that you're working with. Also, you do a lot of research, and, whether that's reading or watching things, to become familiar with the the brand itself. And then also you create characters that feel like real people. Just because they're an orc doesn't mean that they don't have thoughts and feelings. And then you give them all a want, which is sort of the biggest thing in writing in characters. Is, giving them something to sort of go after and then an obstacle in front of them.

"], ["Interviewer: Given the importance of maintaining a character's depth and motivation, how do you approach the writing process to ensure that these wants and obstacles are not only clear to the audience but also evolve over the course of a series?  

", "Interviewee: Well, that is where planning comes in. That's where, it's called, you sort of think that the outline is for an individual script, but you also sort of build what you call the arc of the series. And in that, it's sort of you look at the series as a whole and kind of plot out your character wands over the course of the series. And then when you're working on individual episodes, you make sure that you address that so you're sort of moving the character across the, game board. For lack of a better term, to get to the end result at the end of the season.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you have a strong grasp of both character development and series planning. Shifting focus a bit, could you discuss a specific challenge you faced while working on the World of Warcraft animated series and how you overcame it, particularly in terms of maintaining the brand's integrity while still introducing new elements?  

", "Interviewee: Oh, sure. So when you're working with a brand that's established, it can be difficult because, again, they have sort of these, deep roots, that have, been out there, and your audience In a lot of shows, you don't have to worry about what the audience will think because you're telling them who these characters are. But with something with an established brand, they already know who these characters are. And then you also have this, vast canon, of established rules, of established history, and so that can be really difficult, to address. And so for me, I broke down all of these issues into smaller pieces. So I didn't feel like I had to tackle everything as a whole. I always had sort of smaller, goals and aims that I would hit for each character. And then I would also reach out to, people who worked there to make sure that I was still sort of aligning with, the brand voice. And the longer that I worked on it, the easier it was where I knew I was hitting the brand voice. Because now I had had, my own experience working there and working within the company.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to breaking down the challenges into manageable pieces and leveraging internal expertise is insightful. Now, let's delve into the technical skills you've listed on your application, specifically screenwriting. Can you discuss a unique aspect of your screenwriting style that you believe sets your work apart?  

", "Interviewee: Oh, sure. I think that, for me, screenwriting is a, very intuitive thing. I think of it as sort of I always refer to it as the beating heart. Plot is important, but your characters and who they are. People don't relate to plot They relate to people. And so all of my work is very care forward. Even if you can't relate to what's happening, you can always to who's on the screen. And even if that character is an orc or a squirrel, or, you know, a 72 year old alien or the sun. There's always something in it that's relatable and So

"], ['Interviewer: Given your focus on character-driven narratives, how do you approach the initial stages of a new script to ensure that the characters are not only relatable but also capable of carrying the story forward in a compelling way?  

', "Interviewee: that always goes back to the idea of outlining, making sure that your characters are sort of, pushing things forward. And for that, you really want active characters. You want characters who are not reacting to things, but are taking charge and making choices. And the reality is you also need to make sure sometimes those choices are incorrect because that's what makes it interesting and that's what makes it compelling is having those characters mess up a lot. That's also what makes it relatable. So, yes. So having those, like, active characters making choices, propels everything forward. To the end result.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that your approach to character development and narrative drive is quite deliberate. Shifting focus to another skill you've listed, content development, how do you typically approach the process of developing content for a new project, and what role does audience analysis play in this process?  

", "Interviewee: For content development, it's sort of thinking of, like, what is the the aim of the project. Are you trying to sell a story? Are you trying to sell a product? Are you trying to evoke a feeling? There's a lot of different, aims for content when you're producing that online. And, so that's sort of how I approach that. I forget what the second part of the of the question was.

"], ["Interviewer: The second part was about the role of audience analysis in your content development process. How do you ensure that the content you're developing resonates with the intended audience, and do you have any specific strategies for gathering and incorporating audience feedback during the development phase?  

", "Interviewee: Well, it's really tough. Generally, you don't have audience feedback during the development phase because you can sort of it's death by a 1000 paper cuts. Because not everybody is going to like everything. You can't have focus groups, but, it the really the key is sort of knowing your audience beforehand. And, making sure this is where things like theme and character play a great role. If you're writing for kids, making sure that like, the issues that are facing your characters are relatable to kids. The reality is your audience is going to have some some sort of through time with some some different outlooks in the sense of the technology will change and the language will change, but the feelings don't change. And so if you make sure to sort of adhere to those themes and your characters having these relatable moments, your audience will come along.

"], ["Interviewer: Given the challenges of incorporating audience feedback during development, how do you personally validate whether the content you've developed is resonating with the intended audience, especially for a project with a significant lead time before release?  

", "Interviewee: Again, it goes back to this idea of of themes. There are sort of only so many themes out there. And, you know, a kid feeling left out or, you know, a bad breakup, it doesn't matter if you're in the year 2048 or you're in 1790 2. The feelings of those are always going to resonate with your audience. The other thing is, you know, sometimes there are new challenges that audiences face. And so a lot of that is research. A lot of that is going online, going to where your audience will be hanging out, whether that's looking at Reddit or looking at TikTok or you know, finding these sort of niche niche places, and sort of listening to how they talk, listening or watching, sort of what they watch, know, your audience may have, like, specific, shows that they enjoy. So, like, watch those shows and try to figure out, like, oh, what is it that they're relating to this? And I think what a lot of places get wrong is they get hung up on the stuff versus the feeling because the audience wants to feel something. That's why they always come back.

"], ['Interviewer: Your focus on the universality of themes and the importance of understanding how and where your audience engages is insightful. Shifting back to your screenwriting skill, could you discuss a specific technique or tool you use to ensure that the pacing of your scripts is engaging and effective, especially in terms of balancing character development with plot progression?  

', "Interviewee: Oh, sure. I think that a lot of that comes in the in the outline process, which is part of screenwriting even though it's not, like, technically sitting down and writing your screenplay. And, one of the things that I do personally is, once I'm sort of done crafting my outline is that I read it out loud. And reading it out loud, you can sort of tell where the lows hit. And when you're reading something, it's forcing you to engage with it. And so if you find that you're getting bored with it, then it's you know that it's boring and it needs more or the pace needs to pick up or there's there's a there's a point missing. So that's a technique that is super useful in making sure that, your pace, and timing and action is working But, honestly, over sort of the the course of my career, I've been doing this long enough where I can just I just know because it's my experience.

"], ["Interviewer: Reading the outline aloud is a great practical tip for assessing pacing. Given your experience, how do you handle situations where there's a difference of opinion on the pacing or structure of a script, particularly in a collaborative environment, and what strategies do you use to resolve such conflicts while maintaining the integrity of your vision for the project?  

", "Interviewee: Well, it depends who's in charge. Usually, on every project, especially in television, there is one person in the writer's room who it's their vision. So if I am working for them, I may push my idea but I also will respect, I'll respect the boss unless I think it is something that is, actively harmful, and then I will stand my ground. If I am the boss, I will listen to feedback. I will even well, sometimes, it's called sort of pitching out. We'll pitch it out to sort of see where it ends up. And see, like, oh, maybe that is actually a a a better choice, but we need to sort of follow the story down the road a little bit. If the entire writer's room is agreeing, but, the brand or the, network is disagreeing, Sometimes, you know, we'll stand our ground. Sometimes, we'll we'll compromise. I usually I try to make everyone feel heard, because I think that's important. And, obviously, if they're bringing something up, there's a reason for it. But if I am the person in charge, I am also interested in always the best idea because if it's my name on it, then I get credit for it. But, but sometimes sort of the the I'll I'll let them pitch it out and follow their ideas down the road. And, generally, we can see then whether it's the better idea or not. So, again, willing to compromise because I'm only one brain, but also my level, of experience and knowledge is usually greater than lot of other people.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to handling differences in a collaborative environment is very diplomatic and strategic. Now, let's dive into a more technical aspect of screenwriting. Could you explain how you use the three-act structure in your screenplays, and do you have any specific techniques for ensuring that each act serves its purpose effectively?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. Outline. Outline. Outline. You'll you'll know in the outline. That's why some people just will start writing, but your outline will tell you exactly, like, where you need to go. That's your road map. That's your skeleton, that you hang, your your tree your Christmas tree that you hang all of the ornaments on. So that that will sort of give you everything that you need to to go and do. Also, sometimes, breaking each act out and just, like, looking at one act at a time, can also, like, oh, is this enjoyable? Does this feel whole? Does this feel like there is a, a cliffhanger? There are certain screenwriting, tools. Some people use something called save the cat. I don't like to totally use it, but there are places where I think it's super useful, especially, when you talk about that, you know, act 2 dark knight at the soul, making sure that you kind of, hit those marks. Because what happens is that people sometimes, they just don't have anything kind of happen, and then it all happens at the end. And you wanna make sure that your your, your action is sort of plotted out, but that it still slowly grows over time. And that is, again, like, partially outlined and then, you know, looking at those active breaks to make sure that, it's getting to where you need to go. Also, I find that if you are having a problem with act 3, that means that you have a problem with act 1 because act 1 is sort of asking a question and act 3 should answer it. So if you can't answer it, chances are you probably weren't asking the correct question in act 1.

"], ["Interviewer: Your emphasis on the importance of outlining and using the three-act structure as a guide is a solid approach. Given the complexity of the projects you've worked on, how do you manage the interplay between the overarching series plot and the individual episode plots to ensure a satisfying balance of closure and continuity for the audience?  

", "Interviewee: That's a combo pack of you want to do something called it's called breaking the season. Which is essentially, I actually personally apply the 3 action structure of the outline to an entire season of episodes. So if I have a a 13 episode order, the first 3 episodes will be act 1, the last 3 will be act 2, and the 7 in the middle will be I'm sorry. The first 3 will be act 1. The last 3 will be act 3, and the 7 in the middle will be act 2. And then I sort of plot all of my, my characters need to be up here? Do they need to be down here? And then I sort of individually assign out kind of the plot, and the character wants and needs and obstacles in each episode. And then we individually outline those episodes. If I am working alone like I did on novel more, that's easier because it's all in my head and I've done it all. If I'm working with a writing staff then it's I sit down with the writers. I talk about sort of the issue. We may work on the outline together or I may give them the outline. And then, when they bring it back, I'll give appropriate notes And then there's probably a certain point where I will just go in and, do a do a quick polish ideally just to make sure that it's it's where it needs to be. And because I'm the boss, that's usually a pretty quick process. Again, because I've been doing it for a long time, and I'm the one ultimately responsible for the entire voice of the show.

"], ['Interviewer: Your approach to structuring a season as a three-act narrative is a unique and effective way to maintain a cohesive story arc. Given the dynamic nature of the entertainment industry, how do you stay updated with the latest trends and audience preferences to ensure that your content remains relevant and engaging?  

', "Interviewee: Oh, that's a good one. I don't I mean, I do. The problem is that whatever the audience is watching currently, it's gonna change in a year to 2 years. But whatever I'm working on now won't come out for a year to 2 years. So trying to chase what the audience is currently doing is not helpful. You do wanna sort of be forward thinking, this is where it helps to really know who your audience is Are you writing for kids? Are you writing for bridge? Are you writing for tweens? And then looking at kind of the emotional issues that your audience faces, and then writing towards that. Because the thing is once you're project, once your series is ready to be pitched, or once your screenplay is done, you can kinda go back and put in the kind of, things that will make it more current. But, you can't chase and what the audience is looking for right this very minute. Because, again, by the time your stuff comes out, it'll feel old. Because it will be 2 years out of date because that's, you know, the minimum it takes. To, get something from idea or script stage to out there. The audience to see.

"], ["Interviewer: Your perspective on staying true to the core emotional issues that resonate with your target audience, rather than chasing current trends, is a valuable insight. Now, let's shift our focus back to your screenwriting skill. Could you discuss a specific technique or tool you use to ensure that the dialogue in your scripts is both natural and serves the story effectively?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. I've listened to a lot of people talk. That's super useful. Everywhere I go, I'm doing research And, you can sometimes you know, if you're worried about slang, just being online and sort of, like, against seeing where your target audience is hanging out and then, like, listening to them, or seeing what their talking about. But, again, that sort of falls out of favor pretty quickly, so I don't like to rely on that. The other thing to make dialogues sound natural is you read it out loud. And reading your, your screenplay out loud, even if you're doing all the parts, or sometimes you can, like, host a what's called a table read and have your your friends read it, really gives you the sense of what it sounds like, and does it sound like people talk. Or those characters, how they talk?

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Yes.

'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've led a significant project at Harver, transitioning from a monolithic system to an event-driven architecture. Can you elaborate on the specific challenges you faced during this transition and how you addressed them with the technologies you mentioned?  

", 'Interviewee: So some challenges were maintaining, uh, consistent behavior across uh, this transition period from the legacy software to the new software. Uh, this was done through identifying what is, like, the list of APIs we have, their current set of behavior, uh, what is the expected behavior of all those APIs. This way as we as I led the transition, uh, from the legacy software to the event driven sort of more, uh, new serverless architecture. We maintain consistent behavior and thus induce the element of least surprise, which in this case would be to not suddenly change the behavior of any of these APIs, uh, throughout this transition period. And this was done using AWS Lambdas, s q AWS SQS. Uh, this is all on Python. And some of the, uh, legacy, uh, tools and technologies that were made use of consists of as Celery and, uh, RabbitMQ.

'], ["Interviewer: That's a thoughtful approach to maintaining consistency during such a critical transition. Could you detail how you ensured the reliability and scalability of the new event-driven system, particularly in terms of managing the interactions between different services, and what role did Redis play in this architecture?  

", "Interviewee: This was through so the ecosystem behavior was maintained through rigorous test coverage. And so, uh, use it's made the use of tools like SonarQube and Codecov to measure the test coverage of our application code both before and throughout this development process, maintaining a high test coverage of, say, 98% and above. This helped to ensure that if any changes made, broke behavior, uh, those will be caught by tests and to help cover interactions across services because, uh, our services were made comprised of many different link services. And so interactions between and across services was very important to cover, and this was covered through the usage of integration tests, uh, something I introduced when I introduced the CICD pipeline using tools like Go CD. Uh, this helped to automate this whole process of testing our services and these various transactions, uh, in an automatic fashion and thus automatically be able to catch if any of these, uh, behaviors were broken or changed. And as for the usage, of Redis, Redis was used as a caching, uh, solution, uh, for one of the services that, uh, was being upgraded.

"], ['Interviewer: Your emphasis on rigorous testing and the use of tools like SonarQube and GoCD for automation is impressive. Given your experience with maintaining high test coverage, how do you approach testing asynchronous processes, such as those handled by Celery in your Python applications?  

', "Interviewee: So you go about testing the individual application code that gets executed, uh, asynchronously. This helps to ensure that that piece of code is what's working. And then as for testing, okay, the actual application code that calls this asynchronously, uh, that is mocked in unit test coverage. And so there's coverage up to the point it gets executed, and then there's validation done to ensure that what's being asynchronously handed off is what's expected to be handed off. But then as for, like, testing the actual execution of the asynchronous code, that's where sort of these integration tests or these more, uh, expensive tests come into play. Uh, and that's where, like, the benefits of having a CICD pipeline to, uh, be able to introduce these kinds of tests, uh, becomes more valuable. So that way we can more thoroughly test our systems and thoroughly test not just, uh, transactions across services, but these asynchronous transactions as well and validate that they're behaving as expected.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear you have a strong grasp on testing methodologies for both synchronous and asynchronous processes. Shifting focus a bit, could you explain how you approached the integration with Oracle and Workday, particularly in terms of handling data consistency and reliability across these disparate systems within your event-driven architecture?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. So it starts off with first working with external stakeholders, working with them on what are their APIs, what is their API contracts, working with clients, uh, understanding the client's needs, their expectations, what are the different user stories, uh, ironing out what are the different user stories and, uh, expected user experiences with the product. And then once we have all those pieces together, then we can go ahead and start building out and designing a system that integrates with these various systems, like Workday and Oracle, and supports these different, uh, user stories. And as for, like, data consistency and data reliability, uh, that's where, uh, making use of tools like, uh, so in this case, the servers that handle these integrations with these systems like Workday and Oracle. I made use of AWS Lambda, DynamoDB, and our automatic retry policies played a big part in helping to ensure that if errors were occurring or something was just down temporarily, retries would automatically occur to help ensure those transactions continued. But then if those transactions failed altogether, uh, what I had in place was some rigorous logging and telemetry instrumentation setup via New Relic. And this helped to be able to quickly identify issues in the system and thus resolve them. And then on a per system or per client basis, uh, for if errors had occurred with the, uh, resolution strategy or contingency plan or fallback, uh, for those clients. Uh, depends on each of those clients and their needs. Uh, in some cases, we had mechanisms in place, uh, that not even engineering need to get involved with. But, uh, our client success team can they themselves, uh, empower them to be able to take into their own hands, to be able to initiate these processes to, uh, essentially

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to handling integrations and ensuring fault tolerance is comprehensive. Regarding the use of New Relic for monitoring and alerting, could you discuss how you configured New Relic to provide meaningful insights into your system's performance, particularly in identifying potential bottlenecks or issues with the distributed transactions across your microservices architecture?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. So it's making heavily heavily made use of AWS Lambdas for which there's New Relic plugins and that can be used to funnel essentially all your logs from your CloudWatch log groups to New Relic. And in doing that, I'm able to make use of New Relic's monitoring and alerting to set up alerts and monitors on our various Lambdas, uh, for when the error shall, say, exceed a certain limit, send off, say, a PagerDuty alert in some cases if it's been such a prolonged error. And with the use of New Relic, I'm able to analyze sort of the error rate, the stack traces, and the logs with these associated with these transactions to be able to thoroughly, uh, dig deep into these errors and to be able to dig deep into, uh, what the root cause may be.

"], ['Interviewer: Your use of New Relic for AWS Lambda monitoring is insightful. Given the distributed nature of serverless applications, how do you manage and monitor the performance of your AWS Lambda functions to ensure optimal resource utilization and minimize cold start times, especially in high-traffic scenarios?  

', "Interviewee: So made use of AWS layers to sort of offset or separate out some of the larger packages that is used in the application. Uh, this helped to minimize the deployment times and cold start times for our Lambdas since there's less in the Lambda now, uh, for to having to boot up with with cold start times. I've also made use of migrating our Lambdas over to US East to Ohio, which at the time, uh, Amazon themselves was pushing out updates, uh, to improve the performance of Lambdas, especially cold start times and their performance in the VPC. So it took advantage of Amazon's latest updates to Lambdas, uh, with regards to cold start times. Uh, additionally, with the usage of new reli comm, able to get, uh, deeper insights into the breakdown of what the lambdas are spending time on. So what this breakdown consists of is time spent on, say, on API transactions, web transactions, uh, with, say, s 3 with the DynamoDB and sort of able to more easily uh, identify what are the bottlenecks currently, uh, in our application, uh, what does the Lambda spend the most time on currently, and go from there, uh, if there's an issue with the response times or with throughput in the current state of the lambda.

"], ['Interviewer: Your strategies for optimizing AWS Lambda functions are quite innovative. Considering the use of AWS Layers, could you elaborate on how you identify which dependencies to include in the layer to effectively reduce the size of the deployment package and further minimize cold start times?  

', "Interviewee: So since these are microservices, uh, they're small. And so the amount of packages they have in them is also small, and so it's easy to sift through these list of packages and identify, okay, what are the largest packages we're using. So in this case, our largest packages were diffuse XML and, uh, Boto 3, both of which are very large packages, uh, Python packages. And so it made sense to rather than having to repackage and deploy these, uh, libraries every time we wanna deploy our microservice, It would make more sense, uh, to deploy them separately as a layer, uh, especially as I looked at their version history and found that they're not very often updated as well, these packages. And so if there's ever comes a need to update these packages, uh, we can update them uh, on a need as needed, uh, for when we actually do get updated, uh, by updating the specific layer.

"], ['Interviewer: Your approach to identifying and separating out large dependencies into AWS Layers is quite strategic. Shifting focus to a different aspect of your technical skills, could you discuss a scenario where you had to optimize a Django ORM query for better performance, and the specific techniques or tools you used to achieve this?  

', "Interviewee: So I've had to optimize, uh, various things with regards to Jeng ORM, uh, queries, migrations, uh, and such. And so some of the techniques I've made use of is to uh, use the Django's commands for domingo. What is the raw SQL? Uh, because in our case, the back end storage being used was a MySQL, uh, AWS Aurora database. And so Django has the ability in its ORM to dump out for you, uh, with its, uh, uh, the ORM query, what is the behind the scenes SQL that it's making use of. And so in some cases, I would take a look at that to see, okay, how is Django executing this query, uh, going through the Django documentation as well to see, like, what are some of the fine nuances. Uh, with, say, like, select, uh, related, prefesh, select, uh, related, uh, so those query optimizations there. And then with regards to migrations, uh, taking a look at, okay, what is the type of migration being performed? Is it an update in alteration to a currently existing column? Are we adding new columns? How big is the table, uh, we're modifying? Are we introducing a new table? What form keys are being added and such? And so looking at the whole culmination of data there, uh, then determining, okay, what is the best strategy to go forward with with this migration? Should it be done piecewise? Should part of it be done as a Jenga migration and a part of it be done asynchronously over time as sort of like a backfilling task. And so those are, like, some various strategies and things to consider, uh, when optimizing, like, a JANORM query or migration.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to optimizing Django ORM queries, especially the use of raw SQL via Django's capabilities, is quite insightful. Could you delve into the considerations for choosing between synchronous and asynchronous operations in the context of a Django application, particularly when it comes to handling high-concurrency scenarios or long-running tasks?  

", "Interviewee: So this depends on say your use case of like okay for looking to horizontally scale. Concurrently handle a lot of transactions at once this depends on the type of transactions, too. so if say your application is a very read heavy service. And so you're having to concurrently handle a lot of Rights. "], ["Interviewer: Your approach to UI design is very user-centric, focusing on familiarity and ease of use by mirroring popular communication apps like WhatsApp. Given that you've tailored the experience for Indian transport SMBs, how did you incorporate feedback loops into your product development process to ensure that the features you were building were actually meeting the needs of your users? "], ['Interviewer: No problem at all. The second part of my question was about how you prioritized which features to develop next based on the feedback you received and the data you collected. Could you elaborate on your process for feature prioritization in the context of your product management?

'], ['Interviewer: I understand that you agree with the user-centric approach, but could you elaborate on how you collected and integrated user feedback into your product development cycle? Additionally, what criteria did you use to decide which features to prioritize for development? 
', "Interviewee: Yep. Correct. So one one is the traditional way of looking at it. Like, there is a a rise model evaluating, uh, which features are, like, the first to take. Like, scoring some arbitrary numbers to it and checking the ratio of impact divided by effort, uh, and and then multiplying it with the possible reach of a particular solution. So that's how we would rank the the features, which feature to dial up first. And another thing is particularly one thing I personally try to use is, uh, uh, I have to check whether the value proposition of a particular solution or feature is significantly higher because this was a new product. So the value proposition had to be significantly higher than, uh, what the competing products are are available in the market. So it can't just be a better UI. So, uh, that that that that these are the 2 metrics, uh, or two parameters based on which I decided which features to build first. 1 was the first one was the value proposition, and second one was traditional ranking. How would you rank, uh, which which features are, like, uh, should be developed first? And then, uh, I mean, uh, for value proposition, I might go into little bit more elaborate. "], ["Interviewer: That's a very strategic approach, utilizing the RICE model for effort versus impact analysis and the Delta 4 theory to ensure that your product stands out in the market. ", "Interviewee: Okay. So few things we ensured, like, one one was, like, we ensured which part of the UI needs pixel perfection, which parts are, like, okay to, you know, change a little bit. As far as the technical team, I being, uh, being from an engineering background, I would I would make a detailed specification about which programs are to be done, which APIs are to be done, what input data is expected, what output data is expected. I made sure that the tech team does not have to think about, uh, which frameworks to use or even, uh, what what are the API specification. They just had to focus on what what was the core task given to them. And I I made sure that they they they get all the technical details.
"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you have a strong grasp on both the design and technical aspects of product development, and you're able to effectively bridge the gap between the two. ", "Interviewee: Yep. So these 2, uh, if, uh, the the about the web acceptance that, uh, code on the in on on on the website being chain and then that is impacting our data collection, we had checks in places to make sure that if such thing happens, we have to manually intervene and check which code or which usually, the the the these changes are really minor. Like, usually, some HTML tags, uh, do get changed on on the client website. Um, so those changes we will do manually, uh, check again what what what's the new updated code code and then just do it. As far as the exact content which we are reading, we had validation and already in place to ensure that those are relevant to our marketplace.
"], ["Interviewer: It's good to hear that you had a validation process in place to maintain data quality. ", "Interviewee: Yes. Yes. At that time, I'm I made a alert on on our Telegram, which would, uh, which would like like, it would send me a Telegram message that, uh, hey, Pawan, uh, something has broken because we're not able to read a particular element on this website, uh, HTML. That's how, uh, that's how we'll do. Uh, I I I would want to ensure that this was her part of the plan, but I did not actually end up implementing in the product because of the, you know, uh, constraints of time. "], ["Interviewer: That's a solid plan for scaling up error monitoring and response mechanisms. ", "Interviewee: Yep. Absolutely. Correct. The first thing I being a being a product manager first thing I see like how much impact can a mistake create on our end consumer? So if it's a little payment related system or if it's related to to let's say the user posting those are severe things because without them user cannot interact with the product itself or they have like high repercussions. "], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Yes.
'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've made significant contributions to the digital payment space, particularly in product management. Can you walk me through the specific challenges you faced while managing the BBPS product lifecycle at Bajaj Finance, and how you addressed them?  
", 'Interviewee: Sure. So, uh, bill payments, uh, is a product that is created by NPCI. And then the architecture is built in such a beautiful way wherein 5 major players are working with, uh, around 22,000 odd billers. Those are live on the platform as as we speak today. The challenges that we face on day to day basis, uh, is on the side of every day there is some or the other biller, uh, you know, top performing billers are fluctuating because of their technical issues. So it includes some migration activity that they are doing it, uh, maybe some new changes or new enhancement that they are doing it, or some issues with their operating units, biller operating units, or the customer operating units. So all those types of challenges that we face on day to day basis. Now coming on to the site, how do we tackle this, uh, challenge is, uh, by implementing. So as per the compliance, uh, we are, uh, an agent institute, and an agent institute can have, uh, 2 operating 2 customer operating units. So we have our onboarded additional, uh, you know, customer operating, uh, unit that is allowing us to at least, uh, you know, reduce our failures by 10 percents by, you know, orchestrating the traffic from 1 o u to the other in the real time as soon as we, uh, reaches, uh, the failure reaches the defined thresholds.
'], ["Interviewer: That's a comprehensive overview of the challenges with biller fluctuations and the solutions you've implemented. Regarding the orchestration system you mentioned, how did you ensure the real-time traffic orchestration maintained high availability and reliability, especially during peak transaction periods?  
", "Interviewee: So, uh, there are 2 peak periods that we, uh, are, uh, that we usually have. Uh, one is around somewhere between 9 to 12 a PM sorry, AM. And second one is around 4 to 9 PM. So these are the 2, uh, traffic, uh, you know, uh, peak period at which, uh, the traffic is at the max. Now coming on to the how orchestrator works is on the side of the, you know, uh, we have, um, identified that, uh, failure, uh, rates during these peak times. And at these peak times, uh, we define that this is the minimum threshold at which the orchestrator should start dynamically routing the traffic in a, uh, you know, batch manner wherein 10%, 20%, 30% traffic starts getting routed to the, uh, second OU. And this happens at a biller level. So it is comprehensive to biller. As soon as the threshold of let's suppose 95% is the threshold, uh, the the success rate goes below 95%, the 10% traffic goes start, you know, uh, shifting to the uh, other overview that we have. So that's how it works.
"], ['Interviewer: Fascinating approach to dynamic traffic routing. Given this dynamic nature, how do you track and analyze the transaction success rates and response times for each biller in real-time, especially considering your background in data visualization and tools like New Relic?  
', "Interviewee: So as you mentioned that, um, um, as as it is mentioned in my resume, the work we have, you know, some automated dashboards that are created on Power BI in New Relic. So these are the 2 tools that we are currently using to monitor or, you know, view our numbers. So we have a real time Power BI dashboards that allow us to, you know, see the numbers that are happening in real time. And New Relic helps us in analyzing the performance of the, uh, key, uh, mobile applications or, uh, front end or back end applications that we are running in order to keep these transactions smoothly. So as soon as the threshold goes beyond, so we have our monitoring team, uh, those, uh, you know, that works directly with the technical team. And there are some other mechanisms that are built in place, uh, wherein the escalations are followed as soon as if the issue is not resolved within x period of time, then the issue gets escalated to the, uh, l two d. So that's how, uh, the dashboards and, uh, New Relic is being used, uh, here.
"], ['Interviewer: Given the critical role of monitoring and alerting in maintaining system health, how do you design these alert mechanisms to ensure they are neither too sensitive, causing unnecessary alerts, nor too lax, potentially allowing issues to escalate before detection?  
', 'Interviewee: So, uh, the issues, uh, basis the, you know, past 2 years experience, we have divided the, uh, errors into 2 parts. 1 is the business decline. 2nd 1 is the technical decline. Now coming on to the technical decline piece, we have identified certain issues which are, uh, already defined that this could be happening because of, uh, certain reasons. Okay? So for example, there is a migration activity that has been already informed by our operating unit. So for those, uh, the alert mechanism is already, uh, made in such a way wherein we uh, made the changes at the back end that during this period, the biller will not be monitored for for certain types of error. So migration related error codes or certain error codes that are already being identified in the technical declines, which are maintained in an exclusion list in order to reduce the, you know, uh, fake monitoring mails or, uh, alert mechanisms. Apart from that, there is a weekly or fortnightly review that we do, uh, on the trend lines of the failures that are happening in order to ensure that the alerting mechanism are, uh, upgraded with the latest error codes or the latest error trainings that are there.
'], ["Interviewer: I'm impressed by the strategic approach to managing alert mechanisms. Shifting focus a bit, you mentioned leading the development of a BNPL platform at Mswipe Technologies. Can you elaborate on the key technical considerations you had to address to ensure the platform's scalability and security, particularly in the context of integrating with a large number of merchants' systems?  
", 'Interviewee: Sure. So, uh, AM Swipe, uh, we were working with, uh, you know, uh, close to 7 or 8, uh, major issuers that are there in India. Apart from that, we our business team was closely, you know, onboarding the top uh, OEMs that are there. So we had around 14 OEMs, and the platform was built for curating the offers for the merchants, those who are, you know, directly working with the, uh, OEMs. So for example, Samsung being the brand, they have already 5,000 merchants that are there. Now they want to roll out some offer on the newly launched phone wherein the 10% discount will be given if the phone is purchased via ICICI Bank credit card. And, uh, the offer is available for a no cost EMI product. So all those configurations are built in that VNPL portal that allowed our OEMs and, uh, issuers to, you know, provide a joint offer to the merchant, which later on can, uh, uh, provide this offer to the end user who is buy who is purchasing the purchasing the project, uh, product of that particular OEM. So this included the 3 types of subvention mechanisms augmented by the issuer, subvention by the brand, and subvention by the merchant. So all 3 types of and mix of 3 was given wherein if issuer and OEM want to, uh, submit the product or merchant and brand want to submit it, the all the types of combinations were built in such a way wherein whatever the type of combination that is coming up, uh, can be taken up on the portal. Apart from that, the portal was uh, made in such a way wherein we were planning to offer it to the players, similar merchant acquiring players, those who are there in the market. Their focus is not more on the technology side. However, their focus was more on the business side, likes of the bank. So the bank focuses on, you know, retaining the customer, activating the customer while not working much on the technology side. So we used to provide our platform in order to increase the scalability of our product.
'], ['Interviewer: Given the complex nature of these joint offers and the need to support multiple submission mechanisms, how did you approach the design of the BNPL platform to ensure it remained flexible and easily configurable without requiring extensive rework for each new type of offer or submission process?  
', 'Interviewee: So, primarily, there are 4 to 5 types of offer that, uh, usually works in the BNPL space, wherein the subvention is offered by the OEM. So it could be a percentage wise or it could be a flat offer. Then similar type of offer can be offered by the uh, issuer. Okay. These are the majorly two types of, uh, the I mean, these 2 types or 3 types or combination of these 3 types of offers consist or contributes to the 90% of the types of offer that are getting currently created in BNPL space. Now coming on from issuer side, that that they usually allow 3 types of, uh, you know, EMI option. 1 is no cost EMI. 2nd is, uh, EMI with some different, uh, you know, service fees that they want to charge. Then 3rd comes service fees plus, uh, some interest being charged on the EMI. So all these types of exclusive combination of offers were being taken up from the OEMs and, uh, the issuers. Apart from that, uh, we did some, uh, competitive analysis from the players, likes of Pinelabs, what they are doing because they have the, you know, largest market share in terms of the space that we were working in. So within this, uh, basis, the competitive benchmarking and experience from OEMs and issuers, we had exclusive list of offers, and we build the platform in such a way wherein the combination of a plus b plus c are, uh, you know, uh, around 28 parameters that were defined. And those combination can be joined. The dots con can be joined basis the requirement of the OEM slash issuer slash merchant. So the platform was built in such a way wherein any type of offer is coming up. Uh, we were just, you know, making minor, uh, connecting the minor dots that is allowing us to, you know, create offers as per the requirement of the brand.
'], ["Interviewer: Your approach to categorizing and handling different types of offers and EMI options is quite insightful. Considering the platform's role in facilitating transactions and managing financial terms, how did you ensure the accuracy and security of these transactions, especially in terms of the calculations for interest or service fees, which can be quite complex in financial services products?  
", "Interviewee: So whenever, uh, issuer is onboarded or a brand is onboarded, we use to finalize the transaction file that will be shared with them. And the calculations that are happening will happen on a weekly basis. However, the file will be shared on the, uh, on daily basis. Once the file is shared, then only the funds transfer will happen from brand, uh, to the issuer slash to the, uh, to to us. So that's how, uh, we use to ensure that before making any partner slash brand life, we need to we used to take, you know, confirmation from the brand that whatever the transaction files, whatever the transaction details that they will require in order to perform the reconciliation, uh, we used to do that. Then for phase 1 and and we used to launch the particular brands in a phase manner wherein only 10 to 20 merchants are being enabled on the platform for our 1st month. Once that is done, once confidence is built, then we use to scale it to 1,000 of the merchants as per the brand's confidence.
"], ["Interviewer: The phased approach to onboarding and transaction verification seems robust. Shifting focus to your technical skills, you've listed New Relic and Content Square on your resume. Can you explain how you've utilized Content Square to gain insights into user behavior and inform product decisions, particularly in the context of the digital payment solutions you've managed?  
", "Interviewee: Sure. So Content Square, uh, we implemented on my 2 of the products, which was Instaemy Card and, uh, BBPS website. The main intention was to see how why the users were exiting from the each step of the funnel. So we we used a sunburst chart in order to see why users are exiting. So we identified that headers and footers as the had the maximum exit points. So we disabled those exit points and maintain the contact so that content relevant so that user can read and take the informed decision. That was one of the activity that we did. Apart from that, we identified that there were high risk claim that was happening on a contact icon that was given. So the intention of the user was to see the list of the content that that can be populated. So all those issues were identified using ContentSquare, uh, Sunburst charts by identifying the respective step of the funnel and the percent as of the exit that are happening. So that's how we used, uh, ContentSquare and increased our 2% improvement in the funnel.
"], ['Interviewer: Your use of Content Square for user experience optimization is quite innovative. How did you measure the impact of these changes, particularly the redesign of the contact page, on conversion rates and user engagement, and what were the key metrics you used to evaluate success?  
', "Interviewee: Yeah. So the analysis period was the one wherein, uh, in the 1st month in the in 1 month, we identified there are, let's suppose, x number of clicks, so those are happening. From when user is landing from x one page to the x two page, there are a defined, you know, percentage of let's suppose 10% users are, you know, unable to, uh, are getting exited in the uh, x one page itself, and 90% user are landing on x 2. From x 2 to x 3 only, 80% of, uh, the x 2 users are landing, so 20% drop off is there. So there was a metrics was defined when that we used to track on daily basis what is the behavior of the funnel. Okay. When we launched a new feature wherein the user need to fill the complete form, uh, there were some header and footer designs that were changed. So we started to identify that there is a increase of 2 to 3 percent of exits, uh, at each step of the funnel. So, uh, once these issues are identified, we saw some user experience videos wherein user were getting exited, user were clicking on, uh, some icons which were nonapplicable. So those were identified in the month 1. In m 2, we implemented those changes. We monitored it for a month. In the similar way, the way we were monitoring it for the m one. We we particularly check, you know, hundreds of videos in order to see why user is clicking it. We started calling. We tried to understand why user wants to click on the icon. What are the expectations? So basis there, the changes were implemented in m 2. Accordingly, in the similar fashion, we tracked down all the defined, uh, KPIs that, uh, were defined at the m one end and specifically on the issues that were identified. So the key KPIs that we identified on the, uh, that we tracked in the m two was on the size of the number of clicks that are happening, how many users are opening the page, what is the total time spent, how many clicks are happening on that particular instance that is being re modified, how many users are spending time on the on respective pages. So these are some of the key parameters that, uh, we started to analyze from m two.
"], ['Interviewer: The detailed approach to tracking user behavior and engagement through Content Square is impressive. How did you use the data from Content Square to iterate on the design and content of the pages, and what role did user feedback play in this iterative process?  
', 'Interviewee: So contact, uh, content square allows us to, you know, uh, see the heat map of the page at what section of the page user is interacting or spending most of the most of the time, uh, during the journey. Then we started to, you know, cap start to capture the feedback as soon as user is planning to exit from the page. So that help that helped us in identifying what is the user expectation on that particular piece. Apart from that, whatever the changes, if we have made it, we used to man analyze it using, uh, by seeing the user, uh, videos, uh, basis that, uh, the identifications were done, uh, whether the changes has been made in customer convenience or not.
'], ['Interviewer: Incorporating heatmaps and user feedback from Content Square for design iterations and evaluating changes through user videos is a comprehensive UX strategy. How do you ensure that the technical integrations with these tools, such as Content Square and New Relic, are robust and do not significantly impact the performance of the applications they are monitoring?  
', 'Interviewee: So whatever the, uh, scripts that we were implementing for New Relic and ContentSquare, we had, you know, various tools, uh, that we use to identify the impact of these scripts. So first one was, uh, website tracking tools that were there, wherein as soon as we used to identify there are some extensions that we are putting in. Apart from that, we had our, uh, infosec team that used to identify if there is any, uh, extra script that are being, uh, put in place. 2nd. 3rd thing that we used to do is via New Relic, we used to identify the CLP, f, uh, FCP, LCP. Uh, these are some of the parameters that helped us in understanding why the largest component of the page is not loading, why first input delay is there. So all those, uh, core web vitals were used to were being, uh, monitored using, uh, New Relic for other type of different types of scripts that we are putting in. Apart from that, there are some extensions that were provided by Google, uh, that were used to see the, you know, page loading performance, uh, after implementing various scripts on the website.
'], ['Interviewer: Monitoring tools like New Relic for Core Web Vitals and using website tracking tools to assess the impact of third-party scripts is a solid approach. How do you approach the optimization of front-end and back-end integrations to ensure that the application remains responsive and efficient, especially in the context of the additional integrations you might have to manage for new features or services?  
', "Interviewee: Uh, John, I have not worked on direct implementations of these scripts. When I were given these these products, uh, these scripts are already integrated. So I don't have much knowledge about it.
"], ["Interviewer: I understand the pre-existing nature of the integrations with monitoring and analytics tools. Given your experience with managing these tools in a monitoring capacity, how do you envision leveraging their data and insights to inform proactive decision-making in product management, particularly in identifying areas for enhancement or addressing potential performance bottlenecks in the application's integrations?  
", 'Interviewee: So as I mentioned that we have some powerbear dashboards created for our business kpis or business numbers tracking. In parallel to that we have some dashboards created for our you know key performance of our backend and front end systems. Now there were certain around 10 to 12 API is that are being consumed in the applications? And in that we identified in the business decline out of the 30000 errors on basis. We saw that 20,000 errors are happening because we were prefilling some. Customer information. That was the mobile number that we are assumption that it would be user convenience. But when we see when we saw the data that 20,000 failures are happening because of the error called invalid slasher incorrect customer details and So that was one of the customer details that customer need to enter along with the some customer ID or other parameters whenever the bill was fetched. The customer was getting this error. So when we started to, you know, stop prefilling the mobile number and we gave a contact icon on click office. The contactless can be open in the mobile number can be seen. So once this this issue was identified by Me by analyzing the data that what is happening after speaking to the customer seeing the different videos that customers. Not checking the mobile number is considering that whatever the number is being populated is the correct one and is proceeding after entering the other customer parameter and the error was getting there. So after identifying this we stopped refilling the mobile number and that because of that we were able to reduce the 60% of the total errors that were happening. So this is one of the classic example of I use the data in order to improve the performance of the system.
'], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! "], ["Interviewer: I'm sorry, I didn't quite catch that. Could you tell me a bit about your most recent role and how it has prepared you for the position of Product Manager?

So I was reading organic communities, uh, through AI agent and then converting those, uh, things onto my application, uh, so that my transport marketplace was automatically populated with organic genuine post. Uh, that's how I bootstrapped it and and generated a significant traction in short span without spending any, uh, you know, marketing thing. So the that that that that's about my my recent rule. "], ["Interviewer: That's quite impressive, leveraging organic growth and AI to drive user engagement without a marketing budget. Given your experience with AI agents and APIs, how did you ensure that the data being scraped and used in your marketplace was reliable and respected user privacy, especially considering the sensitivity around transportation logistics? 
", "Interviewee: Yes. Correct. So few things were there. Although I was using AI agent to populate my marketplace, uh, there was still a manual intervention just to make sure that, uh, like, all the data which is going into the my system is accurate. Uh, another thing, I had written some more APIs on top of it in order to validate whatever information I'm putting it. It's not considering like, having any sensitive information, any user specific information, which is automatically lead to our, uh, UI. So I had, like, multiple APIs on top of another or to validate those things. Um, in addition, I had, like, a person dedicated just to keep a watch over, uh, the organic post generated on the platform. If there is any mishap, like, you can immediately delete it, uh, with with the manual control. So these two things. Like, there were, like, couple of more AI kind of agent APIs which which, uh, made sure that every post is validated strongly against our set of criteria. And then on top of it, there was a manual, uh, checking as well. Uh, Yeah. These two things were were ensure, uh, like, ensured. And another thing was, uh, on our marketplace itself, we were making sure that the user personal information, which which are their phone numbers or any any name, that sort of thing, that is hidden from, uh, from the the the other marketplace users on the application until they submit their own information. So the way we ensure this, like like, uh, as I talk talked about, there was another top of APIs chained to to each other, uh, which ensured that, like, phone numbers is omitted, any personal data is omitted.
