"], ["Interviewer: It sounds like you've implemented a robust system combining automated checks with manual oversight to maintain data integrity and privacy. ", "Interviewee: Okay. Uh, so the thing is, uh, right now, I mean, if you want, I can show you, uh, the, um, like, my Figma sketches, but, uh, I'm not sure, like, I would be able to access those files right at the moment, but then I'll explain you the thought process. The thought process was, uh, ensuring what Indian transport SMEs typically prefer. They prefer WhatsApp US. They prefer coming their communication happening with mobile phone over any other apps. So I made sure that our app UI is very coherent with what what WhatsApp UI is and what call logs are. So they kind of feel this app is natural extension to what they have already been using. They they use typically phone calls and, like, in the personal connections. Uh, so one key, uh, feature was, uh, like, instead of having multiple, you know, multiple sections of that which they have to learn and explore, Uh, we kind of did a a call log kind of test in which, uh, the whole UI appeared as if, like, it was a series of call log interactions with other users. So there was post, there was track, there was, you know, call call made, call received. That type of interaction on a unified interface, uh, makes it very interesting for somehow, like, for the, uh, Indian consumers, uh, the transport SMBs. They don't like uh, want to learn different subsections and subsections of, uh, like like, you have typically, what a competitor would do is, uh, like like, what what other competitive apps are doing is they are they're having like, there is a top marketplace. There is a loan marketplace. Uh, then there is my load section, my truck section. Like, 4, 5 sections, it it's placed into it. But, no, but what why users are preferring online communities? Because it feels like a live interaction. Uh, like, one thing after another, not not necessarily categorized into different things. So that's that that's how we leverage our UI insights.
"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to UI design is very user-centric, focusing on familiarity and ease of use by mirroring popular communication apps like WhatsApp. Given that you've tailored the experience for Indian transport SMBs, how did you incorporate feedback loops into your product development process to ensure that the features you were building were actually meeting the needs of your users? ", "Interviewee: Yep. So the thing is, uh, we had periodic feedback loops even before the product was launched. Uh, what what I would do is, like, prototype a thing in Figma and then actually take it to the local transporters and see like, without mentioning it to them that this is just a prototype and not an actual application, just see how they try to interact with that that screen. And, actually, record a screen, uh, you know, tabs and, uh, like, the way they're where they click and what their facial expressions are. I used to, like, notice it and then later studied, like, think thinking where did they feel actually confused or where did they were they were, like, encouraged to click on certain things. I think you asked 2 questions. 1 was the feedback loop. How how did I incur incorporate? And what was the second question?
"], ['Interviewer: No problem at all. The second part of my question was about how you prioritized which features to develop next based on the feedback you received and the data you collected. Could you elaborate on your process for feature prioritization in the context of your product management? 
', 'Interviewee: Could you elaborate on your process for feature prioritization in the context of your product management? Yep. Yep. So
'], ['Interviewer: I understand that you agree with the user-centric approach, but could you elaborate on how you collected and integrated user feedback into your product development cycle? Additionally, what criteria did you use to decide which features to prioritize for development? 
', "Interviewee: Yep. Correct. So one one is the traditional way of looking at it. Like, there is a a rise model evaluating, uh, which features are, like, the first to take. And, uh, I think that typically takes, uh, few things into consideration. How much is the effort involved? Uh, how much is the possible impact? Like, scoring some arbitrary numbers to it and checking the ratio of impact divided by effort, uh, and and then multiplying it with the possible reach of a particular solution. So that's how we would rank the the features, which feature to dial up first. And another thing is particularly one thing I personally try to use is, uh, uh, I have to check whether the value proposition of a particular solution or feature is significantly higher because this was a new product. So the value proposition had to be significantly higher than, uh, what the competing products are are available in the market. So it can't just be a better UI. So, uh, that that that that these are the 2 metrics, uh, or two parameters based on which I decided which features to build first. 1 was the first one was the value proposition, and second one was traditional ranking. How would you rank, uh, which which features are, like, uh, should be developed first? And then, uh, I mean, uh, for value proposition, I might go into little bit more elaborate. Like, you need to have, like, 2, 3, 4 times more better value proposition than than the existing competitive, uh, products. And then that's when users switch from current behavior to a new behavior. Uh, I think this is, uh, this is kind of, like, a little bit known theory of delta for value proposition. If there is a delta for value proposition in your product, then people like like, the the new behavior is 4 times better than the previous behavior, then then people are, like, naturally inclined to switch to the new behavior and not switch back to whatever the old behavior is. So these these two things. Yep. Rise model and value proposition.
"], ["Interviewer: That's a very strategic approach, utilizing the RICE model for effort versus impact analysis and the Delta 4 theory to ensure that your product stands out in the market. Given your technical background, how did you communicate these technical and product decisions to your development team, and how did you ensure that the technical aspects were aligned with the product vision and user needs? 
", "Interviewee: Okay. So few things we ensured, like, one one was, like, we ensured which part of the UI needs pixel perfection, which parts are, like, okay to, you know, change a little bit. For example, let's say on if you want to copy WhatsApp UI, it's good enough to copy the text messaging part and and, you you know, usual, uh, the color the color and theme, but don't have to go as detailed as, like, you know, making sure that the doodles used on WhatsApp are the same what what we are using on our app. So, uh, that's how I would communicate the user details, uh, to the design team that to ensure that, like, you have to make sure that which parts are, like, must have and which parts are, like, okay to kind of go a little bit vague about. As far as the technical team, I being, uh, being from an engineering background, I would I would make a detailed specification about which programs are to be done, which APIs are to be done, what input data is expected, what output data is expected. Uh, that kind of, like, API level specification and what automations are need to be done, uh, these kind of things which we, uh, which I give information to the tech team. And I also help on, like, which tool to pick. Let's say, uh, if you're, uh, doing browser Chrome automation, like, how to use JavaScript tool and selenium tool, you know, combine that automation and, like, which which libraries are best utilized and, uh, to open API, uh, availability and all those things. I made sure that the tech team does not have to think about, uh, which frameworks to use or even, uh, what what are the API specification. They just had to focus on what what was the core task given to them. And I I made sure that they they they get all the technical details.
"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you have a strong grasp on both the design and technical aspects of product development, and you're able to effectively bridge the gap between the two. Considering your experience with web scraping and automation, how did you handle challenges related to data consistency and the potential for web scraping to break due to changes in the target websites? How did you ensure the resilience of your data collection methods? 
", "Interviewee: Yep. So, uh, being a new product and a new process, uh, we were not, like, very, uh, strict initially about, uh, what the consistency, let's say, data collection process, what if the the UI, uh, code itself on the website changes. So that particular part, let's say, if UI of, uh, like, the the HTML code are are changing on the the on on the WhatsApp side, like, the data collection may not be accurate. That part was honestly manual. Like, if there was a like, if program broke, then we we saw saw into the program and then then and then and then fixed that. And another another thing about, like, the consistency and everything, I as I already told before that uh, we had, like, couple of more edge AI agents to validate every post which were which were reading into our system. So these 2, uh, if, uh, the the about the web acceptance that, uh, code on the in on on on the website being chain and then that is impacting our data collection, we had checks in places to make sure that if such thing happens, we have to manually intervene and check which code or which usually, the the the these changes are really minor. Like, usually, some HTML tags, uh, do get changed on on the client website. Um, so those changes we will do manually, uh, check again what what what's the new updated code code and then just do it. As far as the exact content which we are reading, we had validation and already in place to ensure that those are relevant to our marketplace.
"], ["Interviewer: It's good to hear that you had a validation process in place to maintain data quality. Given the manual aspect of handling changes in web scraping targets, did you implement any alerting mechanisms to detect when a scrape failed or when data quality issues arose? How did you manage to keep the downtime to a minimum in such scenarios? 
", "Interviewee: Yes. Yes. So, uh, like, this was little bit hacky in a way that, uh, whenever the program kind of failed to read, uh, any organic post, uh, after multiple iterations, uh, and then failed to read. I don't mean to say, like, there was no organic push at all. The program broke in a sense that the element which you're searching for is not found, let's say. That's when you know that certain thing has been broken on our server. At that time, I'm I made a alert on on our Telegram, which would, uh, which would like like, it would send me a Telegram message that, uh, hey, Pawan, uh, something has broken because we're not able to read a particular element on this website, uh, HTML. That's how, uh, that's how we'll do. Uh, I I I would want to ensure that this was her part of the plan, but I did not actually end up implementing in the product because of the, you know, uh, constraints of time. But this was originally, uh, one of my plan or PRDs to ensure that we have a very high uptime, ensuring that sometimes whenever whenever there is a change in the client side and we are not able to find the element itself to read the data form, uh, we would get our Telegram alert. So I had a PRD prepared for it, but, technically, we do not end up implementing.
"], ["Interviewer: I see, so you had a proactive approach in mind with the telegram alerts for monitoring the web scraping process. Even though it wasn't implemented, it's a sound strategy for minimizing downtime. Moving forward, how would you approach the implementation of such monitoring systems to ensure that you can respond quickly to any issues that arise with your data collection processes in future projects? 
", "Interviewee: Yes. So in future, but it's I know typically in professional setup, uh, Century is used to check what kind type of errors are occurring, what is the frequency of occurrence, and, uh, what is the severity severity of those. You have to have some certain markers to to evaluate the severity frequency and everything. And those all those errors are logged into century. You you daily have a look at it, see what is severe, what needs are, what needs are you measured look into. And I know in typical larger teams, there are there are on call engineers to deal with certain scenarios, uh, but, uh, but, uh, that's how I would I would go. Like, that depends totally on the scale of the project. So daily, we would we were generating around 200 organic post, and at at our sorry. At my skill, uh, this was not a severe requirement, but, uh, but but usually in a professional setup, in a larger organization, I know there are centuries being locked into and, uh, those centuries then have a level wise alert. So sometimes it's a email alert, then it's a phone call alert to the engineer. And then then at the highest level, I think there is there has to be an on call engineer in which personally calls up, uh, the concerned person who fixes the issue if he's not able to fix on his own. So, yep, that's that's that's about my answer.
"], ["Interviewer: That's a solid plan for scaling up error monitoring and response mechanisms. Utilizing tools like Sentry for error logging and having a tiered alert system can indeed help manage and mitigate issues effectively. Given your experience and the scale of your projects, how do you balance the need for such robust systems with the resources available, especially in a startup environment where you might have constraints on time and manpower? 
", "Interviewee: Yep. Absolutely. Correct. The first thing I being a being a product manager first thing I see like how much impact can a mistake create on our end consumer? So if it's a little payment related system or if it's related to to let's say the user posting those are severe things because without them user cannot interact with the product itself or they have like high repercussions. So for those things definitely the trigger threshold has to be much lower if there is any mistake like that has to be dealt with immediately, but the current example which I recently talked about if I'm populating Marketplace from organic communities, that's not a very, you know, very high negative impact use case or scenario or if there are no organic post generated from our online community. That's not going to cause any havoc in any users personal life. They can still use the product naturally without any automated Marketing in world. So in that scenario like that. Then you not be immediate engineering input to be input to be given and another thing like few things to make sure that like depending on the stage of the product. I like particularly for the initial stage products. I do prefer working with full stack developers who kind of know automation front and backend in order to make this systems in lesser type. But even before that I'll see from user effective how much negative impact can certainly make and then that the work. If it's if it's too much for the team too much for the reason not going to impact and user anyway in a very negative manner. So that's how I would like this is a multiple faceted thinking like whether it's a user impact causing or not and whether our team can deliver it or not and then one one Midway approach. I found like usually full stack developers up really fast implemented. So who helped me ensure that I have a very robust system in a minimal effort in more.
"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

'], ["Interviewer: That's a comprehensive approach to training evaluation. Shifting focus a bit, you've also worked on metrics management and ensuring SLA compliance. Can you discuss the key metrics you tracked for a project and how you used that data to maintain SLA compliance?

That's how we track the metrics.
"], ['Interviewer: Focusing on productivity and quality makes sense. How did you ensure that the team remained focused on these key metrics, especially during high-pressure periods, and how was this reflected in your project management approach?

And for productivity, the matrices were discussed with the team leads or the team members productivity were discussed with the team leads. So they actually helped groom them productivity.
"], ['Interviewer: Incorporating HR interventions for team morale is innovative. How did you quantify the impact of these HR interventions on team performance, and did you make any adjustments to these activities based on the feedback received from the team?

"], ["Interviewer: Understanding the impact on team dynamics is insightful. Shifting to a more technical focus, you've listed Quality Assurance as one of your skills. '], ['Interviewer: Leveraging training and deployment to test environments is effective. How did you measure the effectiveness of the Fishbone diagram and the 80/20 rule in reducing errors, and were there any unexpected challenges in implementing these methodologies or tools in your QA process?

'], ['Interviewer: Understanding the categorization of errors is key to targeted improvement. How did you design the training programs to specifically address the different types of errors, and what was the impact on error reduction for each category after the training initiatives?  
', 'Interviewee: Training initiatives. Yeah. So the training program was, uh, arranged, uh, in collaboration with the training team. So there was a trainer specifically assigned for this project. So, uh, the trainer was also part of the team. So he knows the key, uh, errors, and he understands the process. So we discussed with him the number of errors the team were making and where, uh, the contribution was high. The chart was discussed there chart. And, accordingly, the training program was arranged, uh, to we had groups specific groups for, uh, different trainings. So each group, uh, not everyone attended all the trainings. So targeted groups were, uh, allocated for specific trainings. For example, numerical errors, we had a separate team. And for typo and the conceptual errors, there are different teams. So those kind of, uh, training arrangements are made, and that was really successful. So once after the training, we tested them, had a written test and online test, and we understood that about 90 percentage of people were able to grasp it and, uh, come through of the training, and 10 percentage, we had a retraining and tested them again. That helped.
'], ['Interviewer: Targeted training for specific error types is a strategic approach. How did you measure the effectiveness of the training for each group, and what methodologies or tools did you use to conduct the pre and post-training assessments to ensure the 90% grasp rate you mentioned?  
', 'Interviewee: Break you mentioned. Yeah. So the free training, we had a a questionnaire filled up by the team to understand where they are at the, uh, status quo. '], ["Interviewer: Using pre and post-training questionnaires is a solid assessment method. How about the written and online tests, were they standardized across all groups, and what kind of questions or scenarios were included to evaluate the team's understanding of the material?  
", 'Interviewee: Of the material. Yeah. So for this online tests, uh, uh, there were several contributions from, uh, one from the trainer directly and, uh, some from the project managers and the team leads. They gave a lot of questions. ", "Interviewee: Experiences. Yes. So, uh, we also had a feedback mechanism after the test. "], ["Interviewer: Incorporating feedback into the assessment process is a great way to ensure the fairness and relevance of the tests. ", 'Interviewee: And understanding. Yeah. So, actually, I was the person who was, uh, in charge of the updates and clarification process for the entire project. So what I did was I had a manual updates manual, uh, specifically designed for the project wherein, uh, date wise, as per the project management style, we had, uh, date wise and subject wise, uh, updates manual ready for the team. So it is put in the centralized location where a team was able to go through the manual anytime while they were, uh, processing the, uh, claims or anything. So they were able to get the, uh, recent updates from the client. So this one, we also had daily refreshes in the morning to understand, uh, uh, what the client updates were, and we explained them to the team as well. So both ways really helped.
'], ['Interviewer: Creating a centralized updates manual is a proactive approach to keeping the team informed. How did you measure the effectiveness of this communication strategy in terms of its impact on error reduction, productivity, and team morale, and were there any challenges in ensuring that the daily refreshes and manual updates remained comprehensive and easily understandable for the team?  
', 'Interviewee: For the team. Yeah. So, um, what happened was the client used to send in their language through email or during the calls, uh, daily calls, they, uh, mention the updates. So we actually simplify it for the team so that they understand in, uh, simple English. We put it in a way that the team understands it. And, also, we ensure that during the daily refreshes, we talk about the updates and randomly pick, uh, team members to again, uh, talk about the updates to to to understand that they also, uh, know the updates clearly. So that way we reassured that the team had, uh, updates, uh, clearly mentioned, and it was simplified for them.
'], ["Interviewer: Simplifying client updates for your team is a great strategy to ensure everyone stays on the same page. How do you ensure that the updates are accurately simplified, and what mechanisms do you have in place to verify that the team has understood the updates correctly, and what was the impact of this on the team's performance and understanding?  
", 'Interviewee: And understanding. Yeah. So, uh, it is directly impacting in their quality. So what are the updates we get from the client? So, uh, during the weekly quality reports, we, uh, come to know that, uh, if some of the members had done errors on that specific update. So we arranged a training for that team, uh, member. So, um, we came to know that, um, so the team member has not understood the update based on the quality. It is evident in the quality report. So they make errors based on those updates. So they are not aware. Maybe they would have been absent or some of the mechanisms that we had, people who are absent on a particular day, the team lead will, uh, share the updates on the next day, and, also, they mandated them to look at the updates and have a manual for signing to ensure that they have actually, uh, seen the updates and they are aware of it. So the signing mechanism was just followed across the team.
'], ["Interviewer: Using quality reports to identify and address understanding gaps is a strategic use of data. How do you ensure that the training provided after such incidents is effective in bridging the gap, and do you have any metrics or methods to measure the impact of this targeted training on error reduction and understanding, and how was this reflected in the team's performance and understanding?  
", "Interviewee: Then understanding. So, uh, these trainings were conducted, uh, as I already mentioned for the specific targeted groups. Not everybody were, uh, pulled in the training. So those who had below, uh, 95 percentage SLA were pulled into the training, and they were given assessments and understood, uh, about the current updates and other processes. So after the assessment, if some of the team members didn't achieve the, uh, required, uh, percentage, so they were again assessed and retrained into the concepts and, uh, put into test phase of production. So through test phase of production, what we did was we had a shadowing process. So some of the lead, uh, production team, uh, they were made to shadow and understand how they work. So that way, actually, the shadowing helped them. And the assessment, uh, how it impacted was, there was no issues. After the training assessment, the team were able to give good performance. We evidently saw this.
"], ["Interviewer: Implementing a shadowing process is a great way to ensure practical understanding. How do you conduct the assessments to ensure that team members are ready to go back to full production, and do you have any specific methods or tools in place to measure their readiness, and how was this readiness reflected in the team's performance and understanding?  
", "Interviewee: And understanding. Yeah. So once, uh, they were put into shadow, uh, shadowing and, uh, in the test case production, what we do is the quality team, uh, assesses their full production. Instead of doing sampling quality, the quality team does a full quality check on their entire week's production. So that way we came to know that where the actual quality is, the average of growing quality, actual quality. So if suppose, uh, we categorized the, uh, percentage as red, uh, green, and yellow amber. So red, if the people follow in red that is below 90 percentage, they will not go into production. They will be further into the test phase for 1 more week. If they were in amber phase between 95 to 97, they'll be put in a controlled production wherein instead of, uh, processing 100 cases, they'll be processing, like, uh, 60 percentage or 50 percentage based on their efficiency. If they were in the green phase, they'll be put into the full production. That's how we, uh, monitor the, um, their production after the, uh, test cases and the training.
"], ["Interviewer: Using a full quality check after training and shadowing is a rigorous way to ensure readiness. How do you differentiate between the categories (red, amber, green) in terms of the criteria for quality, efficiency, and understanding, and do you have any feedback loops in place to continuously improve the training and onboarding process based on the findings from these assessments, and how has this approach impacted the team's performance and understanding over time?  
", "Interviewee: Here so based on the test scores. The team members were categorized into red Amber and green. So continuously the weekly reports based on the weekly reports even after they go into the full production. They were continuously monitored if they were in green continuously. That's a good sign that they have improved. So somebody moved from Amber to Green that is also a good sign. If somebody moved from the Amber stage to a red that is something which we we need to look upon and again rearrange training for them. So if somebody is continuously on a red and they are not improving they are pulled out of the production. Pulled out of the production and that way we ensure that they don't affect the overall productivity. I mean the overall quality they are full of protection put into complete training. So after that a complete assessment is given even if they didn't improve then we will have to move them to the different team or we look for other options for the particular team member that is a very small percentage which doesn't impact the productivity or quality. And something called Carvey was introduced Caribbean the sense like list of team members for put in the Caribbean list. So all the quality team have specific list of team members where they need to use special attention. So those people have done more sampling quality team will do extra 10% sampling to see how they are qualities for every week and assessment to the production.
"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Hello. Hello.

'], ["Interviewer: Great to have you here. I see from your resume that you've had experience with legal research using LexisNexis and Westlaw. Can you discuss a specific project where your research on these platforms was crucial to the outcome?  

", 'Interviewee: Platforms was crucial to the outcomes of the specific targets that I had to make.

'], ['Interviewer: That sounds like a valuable experience. Could you elaborate on the process you used to ensure the accuracy and relevance of the information you found on LexisNexis and Westlaw for these targets?  

', "Interviewee: Yeah. So many of the projects that I had, for example, when I was writing a legal essay that was further published into my comment, a lot of the information that I had to use from were case studies legal briefs, different types of legal materials where having, like, this mess LexisNexis and Westlaw were essential, specifically in the form of finding codes, regulations, that type of information. And without it, I needed, to bolster, so kinda having Lexus nest eggs and Westlaw were essential to the publication of my article and a lot of the legal work that I have done since graduating law school from helping draft certain contracts from writing different memos. So it's been an important component in learning how to use the powerful systems.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you've integrated these research tools effectively into your work. Shifting focus a bit, could you describe a particularly challenging aspect of using Zotero for organizing and managing your research materials, and how you overcame it?  

", 'Interviewee: Yeah. So specifically with Zotero, using it as, like, a a a tracker of a lot of my sources for different citations, things like that. It was the beginning, the biggest challenge was just learning how to use the software and then implementing it correctly within my research category or a collection of sources that I could input into whatever work product I was creating. For example, writing a legal research article incorporating the sources correctly, and the formatting of all of that, kinda more of the back end stuff. But overall, I was able to become pretty proficient with Zotero.

'], ["Interviewer: It's great to hear how you've adapted to using Zotero effectively. Now, moving on to your experience at Small Business Utility Advocates, could you detail a specific instance where the policy recommendations you drafted led to a tangible change in regulatory procedures?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Absolutely. So one of the key functions that I have in this position is, reviewing different regulations that are kind of put out by the California Public Utilities Commission. And then through research, through different means of using, primary sources, secondary sources, and tertiary sources. What we do is kind of think about how this is gonna affect small businesses within primarily California, but more specifically within San Francisco area. In the Bay Area. And, one of the primary key results that I've been able to see through my work is, California is implementing a new, kind of regulatory rule making authority where they're looking for public comment and feedback, and I'm working on that and using the tertiary secondary sources, I've been able to, draft recommendations of how small business utility advocates should comment to the administrative law judge to make sure our clients, small businesses within the Bay Area, are adequately represented. And in doing so, they've been able to incorporate some of that feedback into the draft rule making. And though it's not published, a lot of the suggestions I've made have been kind of instituted and implemented within the draft rule making that will be for the proposed later

"], ['Interviewer: Your work on influencing regulatory procedures is quite impactful. Shifting focus back to your legal research skills, how do you approach the process of synthesizing information from a variety of sources to form a cohesive argument or recommendation, and could you provide an example of this in practice?  

', "Interviewee: Yes. I can. So one of the primary ways that I think about collecting and collating large amounts of information resources is you know, tracking that information, making sure I know my question, making sure I know my project, and then kinda annotating when I need to different avenues for collecting that information. So making sure I know within these 6 different rule making authorities or within these 6 different procedures, I can quickly kind of format, understand, annotate, I have an idea of where that information is, and then I'm able to kind of incorporate that within whatever writing component I might have. For example, I'm drafting a memo, I have all my sources within the document. I have my central questions, and then I can kind of start from a more broader point of view. And then as I write kind of narrow the question and within scope. So I've been able to do that through legal memos. Through my comments publication, through when I was a contract drafting attorney within the transactional world, a lot of that was germane going through different contracts to incorporate the necessary language within that contract. It was a key component of what I did, and how I was able to create legal effective work, and that was you know, making sure I had my sources, understanding the broader questions and themes. And then as I write, become more specific, using those sources and the question that I had in mind to answer for a client.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to managing and utilizing sources for different legal contexts is quite thorough. Now, I'd like to delve into the technical skills you've listed on your application. Could you explain a complex feature or function within Microsoft Office Suite that you've utilized in a professional setting, and the specific benefits it provided in that context?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. So within Word, understanding the macro programs. So the formatting features, the functions, being able to use word on a high level is more than just being able to write text within the document. It's it's understanding how to quickly and efficient be organized documents, to make it appear nicer and more organized. And that goes from formatting 80 page papers using citations, all the robust functions within Word. But this also extends to PowerPoint, for example, understanding a lot of the macro features in PowerPoint to create a adequate presentation where it's organized You have your notes. You have the presentation. It's not too cluttered or clogged. And while I have good working knowledge of Excel, well, it is not close to the what I think the powers and capabilities are of itself, but I'm much more proficient within PowerPoint and within Word. And specifically within Word, making sure I know how to format organize documents, and all of the, powerful macro feed functions within that.

"], ["Interviewer: Your use of macros in Word and PowerPoint is indeed a high-level application of those tools. Given your experience with legal research and the tools you've mentioned, how do you see the role of AI and machine learning evolving in the field of legal research, and what steps do you think should be taken to ensure the ethical use of AI in this context?  

", "Interviewee: I think it is absolutely part and parcel of legal research and kind of the incorporation of AI within legal research is super important. It's part and parcel to it. I see them kind of blending together and enhancing as a lawyer. As an attorney, the powers and functions and capabilities of my legal research. So it shouldn't be something that's shunned or something that shouldn't be used. It should be used to augment the capabilities of an attorney. So I think within the form of legal research, there's boundless capacity for it to be kind of incorporated, and I kinda wanna be on the edge of that because I think it's super important. For example, you know, if I'm researching, a case law, I can do a lot of my case law reading and review. However, that, you know, that's time consuming if I am able to use AI to more accurately track the cases that I need to use for regulatory compliance within a specific circuit within a specific district that's great. But if I'm able to draw more cases, with using AI, that's even better, and I think it'll help strengthen attorneys' legal research and writing capabilities.

"], ['Interviewer: Given your perspective on the integration of AI in legal research, how do you think the current tools like LexisNexis and Westlaw could be enhanced with AI to provide even more value to legal professionals, and what specific features would you like to see in such an enhanced tool?  

', "Interviewee: I think it can be more accurate in the sense of instead of giving you so many cases, they can give you less cases, more specific to the functions of what's happening. "], ["Interviewer: Reading the outline aloud is a great practical tip for assessing pacing. "], ["Interviewer: Your approach to handling differences in a collaborative environment is very diplomatic and strategic. Now, let's dive into a more technical aspect of screenwriting. ", "Interviewee: Yes. Outline. Outline. Outline. You'll you'll know in the outline. That's why some people just will start writing, but your outline will tell you exactly, like, where you need to go. I don't like to totally use it, but there are places where I think it's super useful, especially, when you talk about that, you know, act 2 dark knight at the soul, making sure that you kind of, hit those marks. The last 3 will be act 3, and the 7 in the middle will be act 2. And then I sort of plot all of my, my characters need to be up here? Do they need to be down here? And then I sort of individually assign out kind of the plot, and the character wants and needs and obstacles in each episode. And then we individually outline those episodes. If I am working alone like I did on novel more, that's easier because it's all in my head and I've done it all. If I'm working with a writing staff then it's I sit down with the writers. I talk about sort of the issue. We may work on the outline together or I may give them the outline. And then, when they bring it back, I'll give appropriate notes And then there's probably a certain point where I will just go in and, do a do a quick polish ideally just to make sure that it's it's where it needs to be. And because I'm the boss, that's usually a pretty quick process. Again, because I've been doing it for a long time, and I'm the one ultimately responsible for the entire voice of the show.

"], ['Interviewer: Your approach to structuring a season as a three-act narrative is a unique and effective way to maintain a cohesive story arc. Given the dynamic nature of the entertainment industry, how do you stay updated with the latest trends and audience preferences to ensure that your content remains relevant and engaging?  

', "Interviewee: Oh, that's a good one. I don't I mean, I do. The problem is that whatever the audience is watching currently, it's gonna change in a year to 2 years. But whatever I'm working on now won't come out for a year to 2 years. So trying to chase what the audience is currently doing is not helpful. You do wanna sort of be forward thinking, this is where it helps to really know who your audience is Are you writing for kids? Are you writing for bridge? Are you writing for tweens? And then looking at kind of the emotional issues that your audience faces, and then writing towards that. Because the thing is once you're project, once your series is ready to be pitched, or once your screenplay is done, you can kinda go back and put in the kind of, things that will make it more current. But, you can't chase and what the audience is looking for right this very minute. Because, again, by the time your stuff comes out, it'll feel old. Because it will be 2 years out of date because that's, you know, the minimum it takes. To, get something from idea or script stage to out there. The audience to see.

"], ["Interviewer: Your perspective on staying true to the core emotional issues that resonate with your target audience, rather than chasing current trends, is a valuable insight. Now, let's shift our focus back to your screenwriting skill. Could you discuss a specific technique or tool you use to ensure that the dialogue in your scripts is both natural and serves the story effectively?  

", "Interviewee: Sure. I've listened to a lot of people talk. That's super useful. Everywhere I go, I'm doing research And, you can sometimes you know, if you're worried about slang, just being online and sort of, like, against seeing where your target audience is hanging out and then, like, listening to them, or seeing what their talking about. But, again, that sort of falls out of favor pretty quickly, so I don't like to rely on that. The other thing to make dialogues sound natural is you read it out loud. And reading your, your screenplay out loud, even if you're doing all the parts, or sometimes you can, like, host a what's called a table read and have your your friends read it, really gives you the sense of what it sounds like, and does it sound like people talk. Or those characters, how they talk?

Given your experience with legal research and the tools you've mentioned, how do you see the role of AI and machine learning evolving in the field of legal research, and what steps do you think should be taken to ensure the ethical use of AI in this context?  

", "Interviewee: I think it is absolutely part and parcel of legal research and kind of the incorporation of AI within legal research is super important. It's part and parcel to it. I see them kind of blending together and enhancing as a lawyer. As an attorney, the powers and functions and capabilities of my legal research. So it shouldn't be something that's shunned or something that shouldn't be used. It should be used to augment the capabilities of an attorney. So I think within the form of legal research, there's boundless capacity for it to be kind of incorporated, and I kinda wanna be on the edge of that because I think it's super important. For example, you know, if I'm researching, a case law, I can do a lot of my case law reading and review. However, that, you know, that's time consuming if I am able to use AI to more accurately track the cases that I need to use for regulatory compliance within a specific circuit within a specific district that's great. But if I'm able to draw more cases, with using AI, that's even better, and I think it'll help strengthen attorneys' legal research and writing capabilities.

"], ['Interviewer: Given your perspective on the integration of AI in legal research, how do you think the current tools like LexisNexis and Westlaw could be enhanced with AI to provide even more value to legal professionals, and what specific features would you like to see in such an enhanced tool?  

', "Interviewee: I think it can be more accurate in the sense of instead of giving you so many cases, they can give you less cases, more specific to the functions of what's happening. For example, if I type in energy regulation, within the Northern District of California, it'll pull up many different cases, some that are not germane But if you can classify the cases further, you know, if I'm looking for something within, electrical compliance instead of pulling up cases just related to energy compliance. They can pull up cases that are associated with electrical compliance and EV charging. Or it can pull up cases that, are tangentially related to that. So I think the biggest thing in AI is ensuring the accuracy and train of thought versus accuracy within word recognition, whereas the word electric or energy and it pulls up that case as opposed to understanding a deeper idea of what the case is about to incorporate that into the research algorithm would be super important.

"], ["Interviewer: Your insights into the potential for AI to improve the specificity and relevance of search results in legal research are quite valuable. Shifting back to your experience with transactional law and due diligence, could you explain a particularly challenging aspect of due diligence in the context of Mergers and Acquisitions that you've encountered, and how you addressed it?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. Absolutely. One of the most significant challenges is just ensuring that you've reviewed all of the relevant paperwork, documents, understanding if there's any title commitments or title issues within a merger and an acquisition. When you're, you know, working on an m and a case, for example, making sure there's not a section where within one of previous contracts that they have to get approval, and and it's just a lot of it's understanding the the meta analysis and kind of the the meta ideas and previous iterations of contracts, not just the current version you're working for. So for example, if you're working for a current entity, and that current entity was owned by 3 others understanding those contracts and the provisions that are still operable into the current contract and understanding who you need to get approval from, understanding the different contract components that kind of inhibit certain entity requirements if there's a voter shareholder or there's, different terms or ideas that are used the previous iterations of contracts, making sure they follow the same streamline of thought. Also, an an m and a is just working with, opposing counsel and understanding that you don't want to inhibit a relationship, but you also wanna represent the clients in the best of your ability. Understanding what to give up and what to give opposing counsel. In terms of drafting an adequate contract that, you know, makes both parties happy. So I'd say the 2 biggest challenges are understanding the previous contract iterations when you're doing due diligence to make sure you're crossing your t's and dotting your i's, making sure a lot of the work is, you know, legal germane and also adhering to previous contracts. So it's not opening up the client to any liability, but also working with your current client to make sure that they are not you know, giving too much of it in their interest.

"], ["Interviewer: Your explanation of the challenges in due diligence for Mergers and Acquisitions is quite detailed. Now, considering your experience with contract drafting, how do you approach the task of ensuring that the language in a contract is both legally sound and clearly understood by all parties involved, and could you provide an example of a strategy you've used to achieve this balance?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Certainly. So one of the most important things within contract drafting is just ensuring brevity and conciseness. And know, there's accuracy within precision. So a lot of contract draft strategy that I use is taking a template contract, understanding what The main point of contention and the goal is ensuring that you're writing using specific words within shorter sentences that convey that thought and idea. There's no need for an 80 page contract as something could be done in 10. Understanding that all the key provisions are in there, and they're adequately addressed to the point. So I think the best contract drafting strategy is to be sure, precise with brevity. So that is one of the primary things within my contract drafting strategies.

"], ["Interviewer: Your focus on brevity and precision in contract drafting is a valuable approach. Now, considering your experience with regulatory procedures, how do you stay updated on the changes in regulations, and could you describe a specific tool or method you use to ensure you're aware of these changes in a timely manner?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. It's a lot. It's through AI AI systems that send me news blast letters. I keep updated through LexisNexis through Westlaw. And within regulatory compliance where it's sending me different issues, day to day ideas, and changes within case law. And that's the primary tool I use, but also through the work that I do, a lot of it is updated daily. So I'm reading new rule making ideas. New public comments, kind of ideas like that. So I would say the way I say updated is through adequate information that's through news blast, through my work, just kind of ensuring that I'm I'm staying up to date with the regulations that are coming through. And the regulatory compliance ideas that are coming through through newsletters and through my work.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that you have a comprehensive approach to staying updated on regulatory changes. Shifting back to your experience with legal research, how do you evaluate the credibility of sources, especially in emerging areas of law, and could you provide an example of a strategy you've used to ensure the reliability of such sources?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. So ensuring the credibility of sources can come through. Several different ways. One of the primary ways that I look at is it's through you know, if we're looking at sources through primary means, ensuring that this study was conducted adequately, ensuring that it's being used in the appropriate manner. It doesn't wanna be know, kind of some nebulous idea, but is it actually stating an idea in our opinion? Then kinda taking a step back from that, has this source been used in other components? Like, if it's being used in legal cases, if it's an expert witness, then it's gonna attach more credibility to that idea. But even diving more into the background of that idea, I think, is important. In establishing the credibility of a source. But if it's just kind of more of a writing source, you gotta be careful with it. You gotta under you know, you gotta trust that if it's coming through a newspaper article, you gotta research the idea, the the journalist making sure that it's intellectually sound. So you know, if it's used in the legal context, it gives you more leeway as opposed to something that you just find on the Internet that's the source. So in assessing credibility, you gotta be you gotta be discriminatory in the way that you use it, understanding the ins and outs, the intellectual ideas, and going back to the root of it to really make sure it's credible at the end of the day.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to evaluating the credibility of sources, especially in the legal context, is quite thorough. Now, considering your experience with drafting expert testimony, how do you ensure that the complex legal concepts are presented in a clear and compelling manner, and could you describe a specific technique or tool you've used to achieve this clarity and persuasiveness?  

", "Interviewee: Yes. So going back to making sure you understand the idea of you gotta understand the broader idea of what you're drafting in the persuasive brief. For example, I used some draft expert testimony for water rights in Louisiana, and I would talk with the scientific experts that were way above my expertise, but I had to incorporate you know, our legal positioning with their super dense scientific terms and ideologies. So it's making sure I understand understand what our key position is. Understanding what they're saying, understanding the nexus between what they're saying and that correlates to our position, stripping away the extraneous information that they provide, to help narrowly focus in within our legal goals and that's kind of the best way to do it. It's to understand the idea of what we have, you know, the broad issue, the idea, the specific component of what we need, and finding the information within an expert witness that scientific and kinda tying that into our very specific legal goal. And that's kind of the best strategy that I've been able to use.

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of questions about your resume and a case study style question to assess your technical skills. Minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to begin the interview?
', 'Interviewee: Yes. 
'], ["Interviewer: In managing the 7-figure global B2B e-commerce project, what were some of the key challenges you faced, and how did you overcome them?Could you provide a bit more detail on your role in leading the two cross-functional technical and business workstreams for the international connector manufacturer?During your time at IVP, what specific strategies or methodologies did you use to source investment opportunities in the APAC region?Can you give an example of an insight or piece of data you gathered from your expert calls and how it influenced IVP's investment strategy?Which of the technical tools, such as PitchBook, Affinity, or S&P Capital IQ, did you find most valuable in your role as a Research Investment Intern, and why?
", "Interviewee: So there were a few questions there. For the first question, I found that the most difficult portion of that project was needing to be able to actually get alignment from a bunch of different teams. So there was the development team that was handling the front end. So we were working on AEM. In that regard. The back end team that was actually working with the commerce system, which was Magento at the time, There was a concurrent services implementation, so there was so for service cloud that was being implemented as well as a microservice team that was working with kind of microservices that needed to be built up, and MuleSoft was handling the integration between all of those different systems, and that was in the middle of of a transition as well. So for my role, it was required that I had quite a bit of input in terms of being able to make sure that all of those teams were aligned in terms of features that needed to be built. So I was quite client facing in that regard. But then making sure that all of the requirements and all of the build was was working concurrently because all of the teams effectively had to move in lockstep. Regarding the second question, with the Team for the connector company. That one was difficult because it actually was a project that started in the February of 2020 before COVID hit. Then it lit up. Being scoped to, to do the same delivery over the same period of time. During the March of 2020 lockdowns. That was a bit difficult because, again, it was a global rollout. So we had our initial meetings where the team from Europe was actually there on Thursday, then by Friday, they all had to fly back. So we had to finish up our our kickoff without the European team. The Asian team was was not allowed to travel at all because of some of the mandates, and so we ended up being completely remote. And just being able to ask questions as quickly as we had initially as we had initially thought ended up being a little bit more difficult. With that one, it was a Commerce Cloud integration. MuleSoft as well as as well as or implementation rather, as well as Services Cloud. And because it was a company that had a lot of international clients, they had quite a bit of Quite a few mandates that we needed to keep up with on an international basis. Things like conflict minerals or or hazardous materials, So the number of case types that they were using was was quite large. As far as what we actually needed to account for. And so the workflows of all those different case types ended up adding to the complexity of that role. I believe the third question was related to my research experience when I was looking at companies in the APAC region. So a big part about this, what I noticed when it came time to speaking to startups was actually having a chance to Speak directly to the individuals that were on the ground. Given that our VP is a growth stage firm, a big part of what we actually were doing, we're trying to identify who the earlier stage firms were in the area. That would have a better visibility and kind of the ability to play closer to the net Then we would. Given that companies had to hit specific metrics before they became of interest, but being able to build those relationships from the beginning was huge. So I spent quite a bit of time on LinkedIn. I was doing a lot of cold prospecting I started relatively close. So the firms that I had had an opportunity to work with, I would go and speak to those individuals and ask if they knew investors that were in the area. So through those types of those types of introductions, I was then able to get quite a bit of a build up quite a bit of a network for individuals who are in that space So that the cold emailing combined with kind of expanding the current network allowed me to get a decent amount of input from both founders and investors that were in the space and actually still keep in touch with a few of them today. So that's been a really helpful growth experience. The next question asked about the the Capital IQ pitch book, and pitch book, tools and affinity that I've used. So I've actually found helpful. I use it the most frequently. And that's actually been really helpful for all types of of different experiences. I think one of the biggest ones was when I was actually in school. I used quite a bit because it allowed me to go and identify individuals and find out how to get in contact with them. A big part of what I was doing when I was there, I was the president of our entrepreneurship and venture capital club, so I needed to be able to source speakers. And being able identify people's names and then get their email addresses based off of Facebook information was really helpful. With Capital IQ, I found that it was actually the most helpful when I needed to do diligence for comps in terms of what I would be able to use as far as best case scenarios. If you will, for for outcomes. So being able to get the the data from public companies as far as what rounds were they trading at, what were the multiples as far as what the revenue to, valuation multiple would be at each respective realm so we could get a little bit of visibility into what it would look like all the way up until an IPO for a for an early stage company that we're looking at. Just kinda compare that to what the the current outcome was with with a company that had already kind of seen that success within a similar sector. In the same space. I believe those were all the questions. 
"], ["Interviewer: Thank you for the detailed responses. Let's dive into a case study scenario relevant to your experience. Imagine you are tasked with leading a project to integrate an e-commerce platform with a CRM system for a global electronics manufacturer. The systems involved include Salesforce Commerce Cloud, MuleSoft for integration, and a customer data platform. How would you approach designing the solution architecture for this integration? What potential challenges or constraints do you foresee in executing this project successfully?
", "Interviewee: So as far as the design is concerned, I've never actually been on this solution architecture side. Most of what I under or most of what I worked with rather was really understanding the way that the business worked and then seeing how the system would effectively be able to extend to handle what they, what they were already working with and what the to b process could be like. Given what was just described, the MuleSoft team integration team would actually have to be involved in every single aspect. Given that MuleSoft is native to Salesforce. That is a little bit more helpful, but the fact that there's a Commerce Cloud portion as well as a customer data management system, there would be some need to make sure there would be a need rather to make sure that the data mapping is is really critical. So from the commerce perspective, I think that let's start with understanding exactly the the end state needs to look like, what the customer's experience actually needs to be within that commerce section. I think there's a difference between b to c commerce and b to b commerce. Far as what that experience typically looks like or has looked like in terms of the the projects that I've been a part of. And so making sure that that is very clear and making sure that the business is is involved in that from the beginning, I think, would be paramount. To that point, I would also make sure that the integration team is along for the ride. Because I found that what actually usually happens is when the integration team doesn't have good visibility into what the end process needs to actually look like, not only can they not suggest the best way to go about handling the integrations They actually need to be taught kind of a second time. Basically, what all the systems would be doing because they sit in the middle and they wouldn't have access to to the endpoints in terms of the beginning and the end. As far as the data management system, That would be more or less static in terms of the way that it has already been built. And so I would say that just a very, very good base level of understanding is, is the way that that needs to go. I think that in terms of actually getting the team together, there needs to be a champion from that side because typically, I found that those types of systems are run by 1 or 2 individuals who just have all of the information. And, being able to being able to proceed without them isn't really something that I've seen done successfully. So making sure that they are involved from the beginning all the way through the entire process would be paramount. And that that's more or less how we design it. In terms of challenges, I think the schedules would line up. I think what I've laid out are quite a few dependencies you know, the MuleSoft team or the integration team needing to get a lot of visibility from both the business side business side needing to understand where exactly that data is coming from, what form it's coming from to make sure that the mapping takes place, and then being able to explain that experience well And with these dependencies, what ends up happening is iteration actually ends up moving a little bit more slowly from what I've experienced. So if the experience for the customer the end customer, is not very, very clearly laid out or understood, in the beginning, which tends to be the case with some of the clients that I've had. Then a big portion of what we actually spent our time on was really iterating and trying to make changes on the fly. As far as challenges, this one is not necessarily one that The integration team would be dealing with, but I've had a bit of experience with this one as well where the way that the project is sold, the commercial side then begins to have implications as far as how the actual work is being done. So say for instance, it's something like a fixed bid versus the time of materials, if the amount of money that has already been spent on the project is more or less fixed and things like chain orders have to come into play, it really just messes with the speed of of execution and delivery there, and, and then it starts to get a little bit contentious because each side has their own their own things that they're trying to to vie for. So the incentives get a little bit misaligned. So I feel like that would be of the challenges is to make sure that it sound both on the dependency side, but also on the commercial side of the project. 
"], ['Interviewer: Great insights on the solution architecture and challenges. What would be the key steps or milestones in implementing this integration project from start to finish? How would you prioritize these steps to ensure a smooth execution?
', "Interviewee: Yeah. So as far as key steps, I would say the initial phases where it's actually being sold are huge because it needs to be scoped correctly. Being able to understand what personnel is actually required as far as what the timelines would look like and what the actual work that needs to be completed Would be excuse me, Would be paramount. So that would say I would say that would definitely be the first phase Once all of that has been decided and there's a good method of working that has actually been established, The next step, I think, would then be kind of the blueprinting. So really getting somebody who has a good functional and business skills to partner with someone who has very sound technical skills on the implementation team. To go in and take a look at what already exists there. This was a big part of what I used to have to do where I would go in and really just get a good understanding of how the business actually functioned, kind of in the as is. So the 2 b section and the 2 b way that things would be handled you could take a little bit of time as you're figuring it out, but really, really sound understanding of what all actually exists within the current day process and what all the actual workers within the company are doing is is really, really required. So I would say that that blueprint phase that needs to be kind of accounted for needs to be thought of really well and really soundly. The reason why is because now you want to start to establish some level of expertise on your own team. So there needs to be an individual who has a good enough understanding of the business where there will still be questions. They can build up rapport with the customer and all of that. But big portion of their job now is to effectively act as the quote unquote wealth of knowledge within that implementation team. So for questions that exist, they would be coming to somebody who's in that role. They would effectively be, like, a kind of a functional lead in that capacity. And it really helps if you are coupled with somebody who has that level of technical expertise because then they can expect they can give they can set expectations rather as far as letting individuals know what is possible. 
"], ['Interviewer: In terms of potential trade-offs or compromises that may be needed during this e-commerce and CRM integration, what are some that you foresee? How would you manage these trade-offs to maintain project momentum?
', "Interviewee: Yeah. So a good example of a trade off that I've actually seen in real time is the difference between potentially having live updates versus something like batch updates. And so this would be a good example of a trade off in terms of because it will really come down to what the customer experience needs to be And Really, what product it is that you're selling that needs to kinda hinge on that customer experience. An example is for a larger b to b connector company, they could afford to do batch updates that only updated every hours. It wouldn't get in the way of their business because these are larger enterprises that are expecting these connectors and cables and electronic parts. They could afford to have their inventory updated on a daily basis And if they actually if their inventory management system wasn't 100% up to date, that would be fine because a lot of what they had at actually established were, for enterprise level contracts. And so being able to go and build to capacity wasn't an issue at all. A second example where that trade off would be would need to be a live update as far as something like inventory or being able to make sure the customer experience, they have a really, really granular view of what's actually taking place is when I was working with a firm that was doing wireless glucose monitors. That is something that is, a, it's a health care item. So individuals' lives are are hinging on it. And then, b, it's also primarily consumer facing, which is what we were seeing. And so people are a little bit more impatient than, than companies are. And naturally, we've been conditioned to be that way, so it's expect So the customer experience needs to be able to to take that into account. Things like live updates are extremely necessary, an up to date inventory management system is also extremely necessary because a customer who's expecting good, especially health care good at a certain time, doesn't necessarily have the the ability to wait And so you don't want to be in a situation where that customer's experience is now a, making them lose trust in the company, b, negatively impacting their life in a way that health care Component's good. So I would say that's an example of a trade off, something like speed. Of delivery and visibility within, order shipment statuses. Would be an example of the trade off. That potentially could happen with with a project like this. 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for outlining those trade-offs. Can you also discuss potential opportunities for future enhancements or expansions once the initial integration project is successfully implemented? What steps would you recommend taking to ensure these enhancements are future-proof?
', "Interviewee: Yeah. So this is, good question. I think a lot of what I've seen as far as expansion and and potential enhancements really relate to the way that the customer goes through the ordering process. I found that that kinda coupled with customer service, like, a really tight customer service to ordering loop has a lot of what we ended up doing that ended up actually helping quite a bit from an enhancement standpoint. So say for instance, a customer only has the ability to order via web. Still the most common way that individuals are going and handling some of these orders, especially if we're looking at the kind of b to b space, especially in electronics. And then if you're looking at health care items, that's completely fine and completely normal. However, a big part of what we were scoping for the next enhancement was the mobile integration. So being able to get people access to these goods via their phone, so it's a much more convenient ordering process That's an example of something that I think would be a huge enhancement that would allow individuals to especially kind of on the b to c side, it would allow them to more naturally indoctrinate this type of work into their, their typical workflow. I think that that's a very important enhancement both from a customer experience side but also from a system side. So in terms of what I believe would be need needed to take into account or would need to be taken to account rather, Just to make sure that this exists is something that has a mobile application building able making sure that you're building your page to be responsive Regardless of what form or what medium you're going through, Being able to handle your testing on your different on your different with your site, your application, your different modalities, I guess. Is a is a good way to put that into take that into consideration. And then making sure that your application's experience and your web experience are seamless between the two. And so if I'm somebody who goes to an application for a website that I typically approach, and go to. I don't like when one seems like it's completely, like, different from the other. I think that the experience should be a uniform one when it goes from let's say, mobile to web. And so making sure that that that's taken into account When, when the initial implementation is being done, as far as enhancements are concerned. My concern. 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing your insights and experiences. Given the complexity of such integration projects, how would you ensure effective communication and collaboration across cross-functional teams globally, especially considering different time zones and potential remote work scenarios?
', "Interviewee: So a big portion of what we actually ended up doing we had core members of each team Colocate. On a fairly regular basis. That way, there would be an e an easy exchange of information. But we did have developers that were based all over from China to India to Belgium and then the US. There is a bit of like, a sacrifice that's required, just to make sure that everybody can at least have some working hours that are synchronous because some of those things do need to take place. But I really think it comes down to the personnel. The leader of each individual Like I mentioned, there was a front end team, there was an integration team, back end team, etcetera. For one of these projects. Those individuals, each one needs to have, like, a very, very clear understanding of what their individual group is required to to provide I think the biggest mentality shift that was required in order for us to be able to successfully deliver this was yes, getting your own work was done, but everybody's, like, active first goal needs to make sure that they are not blocking anybody else, with teams with this highest this high level of dependency given their their complexity. When a team lead was no longer working to unblock everybody else, it became very, very apparent So that ended up having cascading effects as far as slowing things down. I would say as far as communication is concerned, yes, we did have a Slack channel, and so making sure everybody is utilizing that actually is aware of the fact that they need to understand very, very very, very minutely what they are doing and how that implements or impacts the full project. But then the last part is really just making sure that the mentality is is correct as far as everybody understands that, yes, this is the But But your primary goal is to make sure that you are not blocking anybody else on the team at all times. And so if there's work that needs to be done as far as a feature build that's independent and there's work that needs to be done in terms of unblocking, unblocking needs to be be the priority, and that needs to be communicated just very, very clearly and very often to
