candidateBTranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello! This is a short check to ensure that your audio is working correctly. Can you hear me clearly? Welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of questions about your resume and a case study style question to assess your technical skills. Minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to begin the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Yes.

'], ['Interviewer: Can you describe the strategies you developed at Ricoh USA that led to the projected $38MM increase in revenue? 

', "Interviewee: Yes. Well, the situation at Rico was that the marketing department was trying to come up with new offerings for their customers. And so I was brought on board to do the market research and the financial analysis to try and turn projects into as a service. I'm sorry. To try and turn products into as a service type of products or subscription based products. And so what I did is I built a financial analysis and most importantly, the the challenge was trying to convince other people and their departments to want to buy in into this new idea. It's trying to turn several products into an as a service product. But after coming up with the financial models and after coming up after forming relationships with different departments like sales, marketing, finance, legal, get their buy in, convince them that it was to Rico's best advantage to try to change all of their offerings into an as a service or subscription type offerings. They all decided that, yes, it was good to go, and we did it. And the financial models project that Rico would increase their revenues by $38,000,000 over the next 3 years.

"], ["Interviewer: That's impressive. What specific methodologies or tools did you use for the market research and financial modeling at Ricoh USA? 

", "Interviewee: Well, there's definitely a lot of sources online where you gather information whether it's general Google searches or Wikipedia, where you go to market research reports like Gartner Research, maybe IDC, maybe Forrester, Utilize all that information and, of course, turn that information into financial knowledge. Using Excel models. That's how I was able to strategize all these future projections. It's by getting market research information finding the data online, and then trans transforming that data into financial and economic models using Excel.

"], ['Interviewer: Great, thank you for sharing. At Dell Technologies, you mentioned formulating and executing twenty-five new $1MM+ Enterprise Licensing Agreements. What was your approach to identifying and securing these agreements? 

', 'Interviewee: So I worked on a lot of nonstandard complex deals that EMC Dell EMC was trying to sell. And so at the time that I was hired, we were brought into a brand new team that was created, the transformational licensing agreement, where we basically transformed the entire way that Dell does business with their customers. So they were they were licensing out their top of title license and I was able to identify which of those deals were most productive and were most profitable to Dell EMC. I built the financial models and that along with the sales operations team We identified which sales made the most sense, and we did the contract in terms, the pricing, and that led to the creation of, 1,000,000 25 1,000,000 plus 25 licensing agreements that were sold.

'], ['Interviewer: Interesting. Could you elaborate on the types of analyses you performed for the quarterly business reviews at Dell Technologies? 

', 'Interviewee: Yeah. So that was basically core business reviews for the sales department. So, basically, I was tracking how the sales team members were doing, what their projections were, and giving these insights to upper level management. To be able to keep track of where our progress is going so far and where our progress should be going.

'], ['Interviewer: Thank you for that explanation. How did you ensure the accuracy and reliability of the financial models you developed in both your roles at Ricoh USA and Dell Technologies? 

', 'Interviewee: Well, data is very important when it comes to financial analysis, and the important thing is to make sure that data is complete, correct, concise, and current. So I double check all my work, and plus, if need be, I get a a coworker to verify that the accuracy of my data is is correct. But first and foremost, it starts with me. I always double check every number before it goes into a model.

'], ["Interviewer: Thank you for sharing those insights. Now, let's move on to a case study style problem that aligns with your background and expertise. Imagine you are leading a team at a mid-sized tech company that wants to transition its flagship software product from a one-time purchase model to a subscription-based model. The goal is to increase recurring revenue and improve customer retention. Can you propose a high-level solution architecture or approach to tackle this transition? 

", "Interviewee: That's exactly what I did at Rico USA. So, basically, basically, we first started with a survey, and we surveyed a bunch of different customers and asked them what their opinions were for software as a service as a service products, subscription based products. And based on the results of the of the of the survey that we sent out to our customers, we were able to identify exactly how they wanted these offerings to be, how they wanted the subscription or as a service to be formulated for. So, basically, we did the financial modeling to model it out for 5 years, and then we discovered that by changing our products, into as a service offerings, then we could project 38 $1,000,000 increase in revenue because you increase annual recurring revenue with a subscription process. So, basically, after I got the buy in, we changed several products, including printers. That was the case study that we did at Sanrico. We're basically in stack. Beforehand, Rico was selling and leasing their printers and copy machines. And when I came on board, after doing the financial analysis and getting the buying throughout upper level management, I was able to, sure, let them know that it's feasible, it's profitable, and we turned copy machines into an as a service offering for mids mid midsize businesses, which made sense for them because now mid level companies can afford the machinery that they needed to create conduct their business. So that successfully was launched, and we again project an increase in our of $38,000,000 just by the methodology that I that I did was by by talking to several people, getting insights, and getting feedback from customers, not getting feedback from internal partners like finance, marketing, sales, and then building the right financial models that showed the proformas and showed annual recurring revenue how much it would increase by turning all the products into a subscription based product.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for that detailed response. What potential challenges or constraints do you foresee in transitioning the flagship software product to a subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: Well, the challenge would be to help organizations accept the the the the product as a service as their business as usual case in the methods. And the way to do that is to show them that it's financially feasible feasible for small to medium sized businesses to be able to afford subscription because you don't have to commit to a term. You pay on a month to month basis. And with the prices right and if they're happy with the service, they continue paying for their monthly subscription as long as they've received the service and they're utilizing the services from your product. That's the way you can overcome the make sure you understand what the customer wants, make it a customer centric product. And then go forward with providing that to the market.

"], ['Interviewer: What would be the key steps or milestones in implementing your proposed solution for transitioning to a subscription-based model? 

', 'Interviewee: Well, I would work with upper level management to set up those key steps. The key steps would be to get approval from finance to get approval from legal. To teach the sales executives the new method of selling teach them the new products that we are offering. So all these different objectives to take step by steps, different approval processes, and then just get sales to buy into it by teaching them and instructing them you know, why it be to their best advantage to sell their products to their customers on subscription based off And then we can get accounting to buy to to provide some financial projections as well on how ARR would increase. By turning into a subscription based product.

'], ['Interviewer: What potential trade-offs or compromises might need to be made during the implementation of this transition? 

', "Interviewee: Different pricing structures if you are going to end the the term of length when it comes to trying to figure out what is the best option for a customer. Because, for example, small to medium sized customers, they don't want longer time commitment. So trying to find the appropriate length of the term of a contract and then finding goods good products to turn into subscription based models that that the customers will actually attracted to. So trying to find the demand would be an obstacle, and you know, advertising is some way to generate demand for someone these products. And those are some of the things that I would recommend to my future employer about how to overcome some of these obstacles.

"], ['Interviewer: What opportunities for future enhancements or expansions do you see once the subscription-based model is successfully implemented? 

', "Interviewee: I think it gives the customers a bit more control as to what they want to buy, how they wanna buy. It gives them more flexibility It makes it easier through transact with companies. When customers are actually have a subscription based product. So there's lots of bad management. Customer satisfaction, easy to transact, it's more affordable for customers. These are the type of things that I would recommend or would be the future of this type of product going forward.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your insights. How would you measure the success of the transition to a subscription-based model once it has been implemented? 

', 'Interviewee: I would measure this cassette the success by the number of sales at the sales people are acquiring. So I would do constant monitoring of the sales pipelines and, you know, work with marketing, work with sales. And to be able to identify which areas we need to reach. Therefore, by doing so, we can have a team effort between sales and marketing. And to try and get these products moving forward.

'], ['Interviewer: What specific metrics or KPIs would you track to ensure the subscription-based model is performing as expected? 

', "Interviewee: I'm sorry. I didn't get the question.

"], ['Interviewer: What specific metrics or KPIs would you track to ensure the subscription-based model is performing as expected? 

', "Interviewee: For example, I would measure the pipeline as to what the pipeline was looking at, the funnel pipeline, the sales, whether it's a lead all the way down to generating a sale. And report those metrics to both sales and marketing.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your detailed responses. How would you handle customer feedback and incorporate it into improving the subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: I would send out surveys once a year to make sure that customers are enjoying the new products. And then based on those surveys, I would adjust the offerings to make it more customer centric because that's the way you get buying from customers. You make your product customer centric, you make your company customer centric. Then you're able to come up with great products for them. So constantly, monitoring the usage of customers' products, make sure that they're in increasing the usage, and get feedback from them through constant surveys throughout maybe throughout throughout the year, once every few years.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing your approach. What strategies would you use to retain customers and reduce churn in the subscription-based model? 

', 'Interviewee: By keeping customers happy by providing the products that they want, that they need, by finding niche markets that no one has tapped into, these are some of the things that I would follow.

'], ['Interviewer: How would you ensure that your team remains aligned and motivated throughout the transition to a subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: We'll always provide encouragement. I'm always actively supervising team members, but just speak to me. I'm making sure what their skills are, what how or where they're making a a a significant impact in the company. So I'm always monitoring and giving encouragement to feedback on a discreet level, making sure that employees are up to dates on their trainings, and they're doing what they're supposed to do.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your thorough responses. What role do you see technology playing in the successful implementation and management of the subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: Well, I think with technology, you know, with AI driven advances, we're able to identify better customer basis. Customers are able to better identify their products. And maybe through artificial intelligence, we're able to align that technology to put together customers with products.

"], ['Interviewer: How would you leverage Business Intelligence tools to support the transition and ongoing management of the subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: So besides Excel and doing the financial models in Excel, there's also Tableau, there's Looker, there is Power BI that I'm familiar with. And I would take all this data, and I would come up with charts and graphs and other visualizations for upper level management to see what the state of affairs are.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing your approach. What steps would you take to ensure data integrity and security while using these Business Intelligence tools? 

', "Interviewee: As I said before, you double check, double check, double check all of the data to make sure it's correct. So you make sure that the data is complete. Correct, concise, and current. With that, you'll find this dataset is wealth of information you can use to be able to show whatever visualizations you need and what visualization tool software.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your detailed responses. How would you prioritize and manage the key steps or milestones in your proposed solution to ensure a smooth transition to the subscription-based model? 

', "Interviewee: Well, step by step, I would calculate the steps that are needed to transition to the state model, but to a subscription state model. But, basically, just working with finance and working with accounting to make sure that everything is right, to make sure that we understand ASC's 06 guidelines, which are guidelines that are set for, recognizing revenue with respect to subscription based products. So just having a good sense of ASC 606 and working with accounting. We are better able to tackle some of these issues in bubbles.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your insights. What potential risks do you foresee in this transition, and how would you mitigate them? 

', "Interviewee: Well, the potential risk is that you just never know if the customer is going to stick with the subscription product. And if they cancel early, then you are you're out of luck. And you lose some AR. So basically, just keep the customer informed, keep the customer happy, make sure that the salespeople are always in constant contact with the customers to make sure that we don't lose that customer. We keep growing our ARR.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your thorough responses. How would you handle competition and ensure your subscription-based model stands out in the market? 

', 'Interviewee: Well, I would do competitive analysis to try and check and see what our competitors were doing, what their products were, what were good and bad about their products, and give all these detailed market research reports to upper level management to know what the other people are doing, what the other players are doing, and how we can stay competitive ourselves.

'], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing your approach. How would you ensure continuous improvement and innovation in the subscription-based model after its initial implementation? 

', "Interviewee: I'm working with developers, making sure that there's constant innovation in the product. If the product stays stale, then it's not going to sell for much longer. So just by constantly innovating and working with develop teams, coming up with new ideas and brainstorming, People keep up with technology and make even better technology to keep people, keep customers happy with their subscription based products.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your detailed responses. How would you align the subscription-based model with the overall strategic goals of the company? 

', "Interviewee: Number 1 priority because it's a transition that the company, Rico, that I was working with beforehand, which trying to do. They made it their North Star project, which is trans to transform all the products into as a service or subscription type products. And so, therefore, just, you know, that would be the best best to do is just stay on it and to be humble about your work, but also to be prepared with what challenges might come your way.

"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing your approach. How would you communicate the benefits of the subscription-based model to both internal stakeholders and customers? 

', 'Interviewee: Well, through through memos, through newsletters, and through PowerPoint presentation, I would do quarterly to make sure that all levels of management knew exactly how things turn.

'], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your insights. How would you ensure that the pricing strategy for the subscription-based model is competitive and attractive to customers? 

', 'Interviewee: I would do a pricing comparison with other products from other competitors in the market. That sometimes means, like, mystery or secret shopping, and just understand what the competitors products are, understand their pricing, and make our pricing similar to theirs, if not even more competitive to be able to get a greater market share for our product.

'], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

"], ["Interviewer: Recognition and rewards are indeed powerful motivators for employees. In addition to individual recognition, do you also track team performance metrics, and if so, how do you ensure that team dynamics and collaboration are fostered while still recognizing individual contributions?  
", 'Interviewee: Yeah. Our team was measured. The team performance also because there are some different, uh, departments. So we compare the quota data, and if we are doing good, like, uh, that also recognized. The teamwork also recognized in the quarterly meetings. Yeah. So after that, uh, if there are any such type of improvement which they are required, like, uh, we the people from our email regions goes to any region people and tell them that, uh, where the where the things can be improved. Like, all the teams must have the same timeline. Like, if we are taking 10 minutes, mostly the other team take 11 minutes or 12 minutes, max to max, 12 minutes. And if there are any diff discrepancies in that, we solve that. That is correct. Like, uh, what we do that we come sometime we did the night shift, and sometime we did the evening shifts. And what happen if that particular employee is not available? It may be. It may do not be not available. But what we do that, we drop an email, and, uh, we can come back and check later. And if, uh, is there any type of emergencies there, we can connect with them because sometime it's happened. We need to connect with that employee and which we need to check what's happening. And knowledge transfer is must. So, yeah, uh, the that time zone issue, which it is not impacting us much more because the our like, in Amazon, what happened is that they are working 247. That, uh, sometime evening shift will work, sometime night shift will work, sometime morning shift will work. So time zone issue, it was an autumn barrier in Amazon because it works on 247 environment. But, uh, yeah, uh, we maintain that English language is must for every employee. "], ["Interviewer: Maintaining English as the common language is a practical approach to ensure effective communication across global teams. ", "Interviewee: Yeah. As I can told you that if someone is sitting in the Paris office, they usually speak in French. So we have regional department also for them. "], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

And then just like a blockchain, it can have other details, like, uh, during the life cycle of trade, what what all things had happened. And, uh, if there are losses, like, uh, one one can have another look, what could have been done well, and, uh, what would, uh, ideal situation would have demanded, when should have the book losses. So, uh, sort of like a equal into a blockchain ledger, you can have a decision making ledger for a for an AI, for regulatory requirement, and for the transparency. Like, whatever has been done, why it has been done. Thanks.

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}
candidateBTranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of questions about your resume and a case study style question to assess your technical skills. Minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to begin the interview?
', 'Interviewee: Ready. 
'], ['Interviewer: Great! Can you elaborate on the automation project you spearheaded at Giantleap Capital for screening public equities, and what technologies you used?
', 'Interviewee: I was working with a team of 3, and we were using chat GPD, Bloomberg, and Claudia. 
'], ['Interviewer: How did the automation of public equities screening impact the overall efficiency and decision-making process at Giantleap Capital?
', 'Interviewee: To basically augment So we were able to use these tools to reduce the turnaround time that we needed to screen 1 company. From, I would say, more than a week to 2 days. This enabled us to screen 10 companies in the same time so that the general partners could evaluate more companies in the same amount of time. So it quickened the pace of decision making it was also very efficient in terms of where we put the number of hours of a day Instead of doing work that AI can do. 
'], ['Interviewer: That sounds impressive. Could you provide more details on the methods or criteria you used for sourcing and evaluating early-stage deals at 9Unicorns Accelerator Fund?
', 'Interviewee: Sure. Most of the sourcing was network driven. So I would reach out to people in my network network, both start up founders, other venture capitalists, people who graduated from these schools people who were switching jobs to understand if they were starting something on their own, if there was any interesting opportunity that were Interesting enough to look at. And I was also speaking to VCs who were late stage VCs who had passed on a opportunities because they were too early for them. And we were looking at all of those opportunities to source start ups in the early stage across sectors. Yep. 
'], ["Interviewer: It's interesting how network-driven sourcing was for you. How did you go about pitching these early-stage deals to the Investment Committee and what key aspects did you focus on during your pitches?
", "Interviewee: So the main key process to pitch and pitch a company to the investment committee was after we conducted a very deep due diligence. I had calls I had multiple calls with the start up founders to understand the business model, the strengths, the competitive landscape, how they were benefited to start this project or company? What was the USP of the team? And then I designed pictures which were basically investment memos that was sent to the committee before a Zoom call was planned. With 4 to 5 different startups pitching at any given point in time. So it was a 1 hour meeting in which 4 to 5 startups used to come and pitch like, maybe 10 minutes to the investment committee. I'm sorry. What was the follow-up question that you asked? 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for the detailed explanation. My follow-up is: Can you describe how you streamlined cross-functional workflows at 9Unicorns Accelerator Fund and the specific tools or techniques used to achieve this?
', 'Interviewee: Okay. So at 9 unicorns to complete a deal closure process, right, from sourcing the deal until signing of the SHA. Is the shareholders agreement. There were at least 4 teams involved in any deal. These included the investment team at the fund, the lawyers, the transaction advisers who were doing financial due diligence and background checks. The fund administrator administration fund, team, which was involved in making sure that the check is issued to the right team. And, yeah, I think they were these. So I basically built a tracker and worked with all of these teams to make sure that one, we follow-up process flow. So in order to make sure we do that, at that point in time, we were using Google Sheets. Which was based and designed in a way that every team gets a notification when a task is due at their end So this made sure that we did every task and this reduced the time from closing a deal in 45 days to just 15 days. We were working on tools and techniques like Google Sheets, Calendaring. A lot of, I would say, email trails that were set into place. There were formats and criteria set into place. And any other tool that I can think of No. Mostly these. 
'], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing those details. Now, moving into the case study portion: Imagine you are tasked with creating an AI-driven tool to evaluate early-stage startups for potential investment, leveraging your experience and the technologies you mentioned. Can you describe the high-level solution architecture or approach you would take to build this tool?
', "Interviewee: Very interesting. So I would divvy up So into 3 parts for early stage investing. Analyzing the market, analyzing the team, analyzing the product. These are the 3 key things that I would look at when evaluating an early stage investment, especially the team. Now how would an AI do this? I would think that the market piece would be very easy to build On EA. So when I say market, it's basically analyzing, 1, is there a need for the product? 2, how big is the market? 3 what is the competitive landscape that looks like? Say for example in India, or US. For a market For example, pet supplies. So all of these things can be AI built or driven Once we can set up information sources that the AI can learn From Now these sources could be anything and everything right from consumer behavioral changes, how is the market moving, what are the revenue streams looking like in some industries, Do we see a niche popping up? Do we see any new I would say, yeah. So these things. The second piece, which is the team, I think is something that I would most rely on a human To evaluate, when I say team, it's so after doing a basic check, which again can AI can do, which is what's the team pedigree, where what's the education background? What's their professional qualification? Why are they best suited to start this company, etcetera, and what's the dynamic of the Team's truck structure, what is the equity split, etcetera. All of these things can be automated, but what I would rely a human on for is gauging the personality, the preferences of how they've worked with each other, Are they hustlers? Do they have it in them to start a company? Do they have it in them to pivot? Because a lot of early stage companies pivot. So all of those things. And the last piece is the product. How will I use AI for the product? Depends on what the product is. If it's a software or a tech product, I'm sure we can set up AI tools to test it. To understand the metrics, the user acquisition, what's the MAUD you like? What's the usage frequency, like, etcetera. But if it's consumer product, say, for example, a sunglass, I would have to think of more ways to incorporate AI in the evaluation process. Sorry about the long driven 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for your thorough approach. Could you identify potential challenges or constraints you might face when implementing this AI-driven tool, particularly in evaluating early-stage startups across diverse industries?
', "Interviewee: So as I mentioned, one is the biggest piece of the puzzle is the team in early stage investing, and I'm not sure on how we can use AI to analyze the personalities of a person and, like, the behavioral behaviors of a person, their decision making skills, are they hustlers, also the dynamic between the cofounders, think that comes, at least to me, It came after multiple conversations, And getting a knack of how to analyze a founder's thought process. I'm sure we can build an AI around it. But it might take time. So it is a challenge in terms of AI is built on reinforcement learning or structured learning But those learnings are based off of Like, I would say inputs, But sometimes you do not have enough inputs to drive these decisions at a artificial intelligence level. That's one. The second is in terms of market, AI can build on inferences based on existing trends, But a lot of times, early stage investments are based On a trend which is new. So there is no past history or data. To infer from. So I think that could be a limitation When judging startups from an AI perspective. Also, I think biases So already we have a lot of biases So start ups founded by women founders, for example, or people of color. I don't know if there's any bias that is baked into AI models that could let very good opportunity slip out of the gaps. Because of inbuilt biases. You might have heard of the Amazon's AI Resume Screener. That had very strong biases built inbuilt Within So, yeah, something to fight that. 
"], ["Interviewer: Great points you've raised there. What do you think would be the potential benefits or impacts of successfully implementing this AI-driven tool for evaluating early-stage startups?
", "Interviewee: I'm definitely sure it will save a lot of time. So all of that time can be redirected towards basically evaluating more opportunities or working with these startups to actually grow the businesses. So a lot of sourcing and evaluation part of the job converts into portfolio development, operational efficiencies that VC can help bring on the table. That's one I think another benefit is that AI could actually spot trends that humans fail to spot. Definitely, it has been proven. I think AI is 25% better at predicting not 25%, 25 times better at predicting than a human. And less prone to error. So we will definitely be more it could be a scenario where we invest in more profitable or more investable businesses so there are less fallouts from a portfolio for a VC. So, yeah, these are the few benefits that I can think of. 
"], ['Interviewer: Given these benefits, what would be the key steps or milestones you would prioritize in implementing this AI-driven tool for evaluating startups?
', "Interviewee: I think in terms of milestones to implement, I would definitely think so. We already used tech tools like Affinity to keep a track of sourcing and networking. I think, if I add a layer of AI, we can therefore, the entire piece of analyzing markets and analyzing trends to AI. So I would say that would be the first milestone for me. So if I categorize analyzing any early stage opportunity into market, product, and team, I would defer the market piece to AI, and that would be the first milestone I would work with AI on. In terms of the second milestone, I would think about how can I automate the day to day mundane tasks and defer it to AI? So, as I said, early stage VCs are all about networking. So, basically, knowing about the right deal at the right time and getting into that deal. And getting a bite of it. But for that, we need to do a lot of networking, setting up calls, meeting people. I think a lot of scheduling, calendaring can be 4 2 ai. That already is Done. To a a very large extent. In terms of product, I would also, therefore, I would say like so say, for example, there's a SaaS matrix. You can set up Benchmarks to analyze, okay, is this deal even worth my time? By putting in user base or revenue numbers or churn or what's the repeat Customer intake, etcetera. So all of these things can again be automated and Therefore, to AI in terms of a milestone. Yeah. 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for outlining those steps. Can you discuss potential trade-offs or compromises that might need to be made during the implementation of this AI-driven tool?
', "Interviewee: I'm thinking. Sorry. So, I would say compromise would be 1, we might be favoring something that has been proven to be successful in the past, and we are expecting it to be successful in the future as well. So for example, my criteria of team product and market. That criteria might be redefined over time. But AI might still keep rewarding startups that have great team product and market. But there might be a 4th criteria that might just stem up. Say, for example, AI capabilities. And because we have not built that into our learning database, the AI is not inferring from that new criteria that being built. That that could be a compromise. That we might have to sign up for. 
"], ['Interviewer: What do you see as the opportunities for future enhancements or expansions of this AI-driven tool once it is successfully implemented?
', "Interviewee: I think the opportunities that I can imagine are more on the synergistic side of things. Right now, VCs operate mostly in silos. When they're evaluating opportunities. So one opportunity is very unique and boxed out from another opportunity. I think AI will be very smart to info from multiple investments of the same VC or of different VCs to infer how we can synergistically Improve business models. So it could be somewhere like, okay. These 2 companies partner where one is a supplier, one is a contractor. Or a client, and they can increase their revenues just by that partnership. But AI would be the first one to infer, okay. This Square peg goes into this square hole. And I think that is an opportunity that humans may not be as fast to leverage as an AI could be. Given they have the right criterias to analyze opportunities. 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for sharing those insightful responses. Now, how would you approach integrating this AI tool into the existing workflows at a venture capital firm to ensure minimal disruption and maximum adoption?
', "Interviewee: Firstly, I would imagine that every workflow would basically come on one platform. So every stakeholder of the VC interacts with the same platform. Platform. So one, we have everyone on the one on one platform working So right from scheduling meetings, setting up calendar invites to, signing the shareholders agreement. Everything happens on one platform. So one is bringing everyone on the same page. 2nd, in order to not disrupt, the workflow, anything that is going on so AI has access to my meeting notes, to my video interviews, to my Zoom calls with founders. So every data point is still in the same place that I log. But AI has access to it so that it can infer details from it. That's pretty easy, I would say. In terms of analyzing founders, I'm sure there could be base to understand how a person thinks. By giving them case studies or by giving them, by asking more around how they took decisions in their businesses. And we can have AI also coanalyze or copilot with the venture capitalist Okay. Is this a person I think is a hustler or is this a person I can rely on in terms of crisis decision making? So we can, like, copilot the entire process. That is one way to not disrupt any existing workflow, but have AI come in and partner in every step of the way. 
"], ['Interviewer: What metrics or key performance indicators would you monitor to evaluate the success of this AI-driven tool once it has been implemented at a venture capital firm?
', "Interviewee: So the KPIs could be as basic as okay, is my analysis and AI's analysis like, how correlated are they? When I talk about analyzing the team? So are my inferences and AI inferences correlating? If there's a high positive correlation, that means the AI is learning how to analyze and evaluate a team. For markets, if the AI is able to spot trends in time, So a KPI could be how accurate the AI is in terms of analyzing and spotting trends. So we can again, so this is a hindsight analysis or KPI. That okay. For the 1st 6 months, the AI analyzes trends For the next 6 months, we see if those are accurate. If they are, that means the AI has actually performed well on that KPI. So that could be one KPI. And the last KPI in terms of product could be how strong is AI crunching numbers? So if the revenue and SaaS matrix, for example, are crunched down by AI, and they can forecast. Okay. This is the forecast for the next year's revenue. And if those forecasts are correct, again, accuracy could be a KPI here. So these are the few things that come to the top of my mind. 
"], ['Interviewer: Thank you for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateATranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Start the interview? Yes. Yes.

'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've had extensive experience in leading business operations and driving profitability. Can you walk me through a specific example of how you implemented a new system or process that directly led to increased profitability during your time at the Global Legal Law Firm?  

", "Interviewee: Firm? Uh, yes. Uh, thanks for the question. Uh, when I got to this firm, there were about 18 people, and I'll start with one example from in the people area. Uh, the way in which the firm had been doing, uh, recruiting, onboarding, and training performance management. Really, the entire HR process was very basic. And frankly, the the owners of the firm didn't have any time to really focus on it. So I instituted different processes for each stages of that in terms of recruiting, in terms of, uh, the interviewing process. Uh, previously, one partner would interview somebody and the next day the person would show up for work there. Uh, that to me wasn't the best approach. It was I thought it was better to give the candidate an opportunity to see and meet more of the firm and its people, uh, as well as get other people at the firm invested in the success and evaluation of of each candidate. Uh, so we changed that. We grew from 18 to 29 people in, I think, 3 months, maybe 4. That was one thing. There was no performance. I'll just give one more example. Uh, there was there were they were doing good job with 1 on ones on a regular basis, but there were no uh, criteria objective criteria by which people were all being measured. As a result, the paralegals, the attorneys, uh, and the administrative staff didn't know really how they were performing. So when I got to that firm and talked to the employees, one of the biggest things they said was they liked working there, but they really they didn't know how they were doing even though I knew some of them were doing really well from the owner standpoint and some were not doing well. So I instituted a process, uh, by which each different type of employee was measured by in terms of certain competencies and in terms of different activities that they routinely performed a significant amount of time on. Uh, and that process is I think really helping. It actually performance and their, uh, performance the and their their, uh, performance improvement. Thank you.

"], ["Interviewer: That's a comprehensive approach to enhancing HR processes and performance management. Shifting focus to the financial side, could you elaborate on how you restructured the firm's financial reporting and budgeting systems to improve transparency and accountability? What specific tools or methodologies did you introduce for this purpose?  

", "Interviewee: For this purpose. Uh, so there were a couple of things. When I got to the firm, one of the first things I did was I looked at the financials. They were using QuickBooks and, uh, in looking at it, I was looking at their prior year, which had which should have been closed but wasn't. Uh, so I started in late March. Uh, there are calendar year taxpayers. So 3 months had gone by. The 2022 had not yet, uh, the books weren't closed. And in reviewing what was in QuickBooks, it was clear they I understood why they weren't closed. It was very unclear what was going on. Uh, and even by June, I had been there for 2 months and they still weren't closed. There was an external bookkeeper. So one of the things I did, uh, I was the president of the firm, not the controller or the CFO. And as a result, I wasn't going to spend all of my time doing that. That wouldn't have made sense. So I looked into outsourcing this, uh, these processes, and I considered also in sourcing it. And when I was lucky enough to recruit successfully, the CPA for the California Society of CPAs, which I thought of as a great get because I feel like, you know, if you can get the person doing 2 counting for the accounting professionals in California, you probably got the right person. And she was a fantastic fit, uh, and had been with a number of organizations that that, you know, the firm that this firm that we're talking about had when I left 29 people. Uh, she had been at firms with 800 people. So she really knew what she was doing and she was very excited about the opportunity and working with a growing company again. So that was one thing to do just to get the financials right. With respect to some tools and processes I put in place, the firm f it had been around for about 15 years. They never did a budget for the firm, and they never did, uh, case budgets. So I developed a template for the firm's budget, uh, and I also put in place a template and processes for developing budgets, uh, for actual cases or legal matters, uh, so that the firm could look at the ROI of their clients of different types of matters, etcetera. Uh, thank you.

"], ["Interviewer: Your approach to financial management and the strategic hiring of the CPA is quite insightful. Regarding the development of case budgets and ROI analysis for clients, how did you integrate this data-driven approach into the firm's decision-making processes? Were there any challenges in getting the team to adopt these new methodologies, and if so, how did you address them?  

", "Interviewee: Stem. Great questions. Thank you. Uh, so when you have budgets, you obviously can then look to see how you're performing against them, which we did on a monthly basis, uh, depending on the cases. I mean, this process was just implemented and and we we've so we didn't it was going smoothly. I mean, getting people to adopt, people who had been doing legal work for 10 years, 15 years, who had never done a budget before, those types of people sometimes will feel like, why am I doing this? This is just taking up my time when I could actually be billing for work, which I totally understand. I felt that way as a professional 30 years ago when I started. Um, you know, I was like, well, why do I need a work plan even since I know how to do the work? Why do I have to plan it? Uh, but, obviously, if you're going to work with others, having a work plan and a coordinated approach can be much better. It reduces risk in case you or somebody else on the team isn't available. So like a like a good work plan that's implemented properly, uh, the budget serve to bring the team together, help them with accountability, uh, help us reassess what type of services made sense. Some of the services we're offering, uh, like the firm had been dabbled in collections business for for years on and off. And the the results of this made it clear that that was an area that the firm could pursue, uh, from a financial standpoint, uh, if it wanted to. Like, it made sense to do that from an ROI standpoint based on just the the budgets and the return on investments shown by looking at budget to actuals with respect to just the costs and the return on that particular type of matter. The the biggest pushback really was from 1 of the there were 2 partners who owned the firm, and one of them this is kind of going a little bit of field from the financial angle. But the biggest issue at the firm was one of the attorneys wanted to grow from the 18 people that I came in when they that they had when I came in to 900, uh, attorneys. Uh, whereas his partner, his elder partner who had actually started the firm, uh, was more like, well, why don't I just, you know I would do better if I only had 10 attorneys or 5 attorneys because I can manage that. So I think he had I think he had gone through the, you know, 10 years of trying to manage a a small law firm and wanting to grow, but finding it very challenging to find the right people, uh, especially because as I suggested before, he didn't have the right recruiting process in place, the onboarding processes, the training. There was no training at all done there in a systematic manner. Of course, there was one off training, uh, and there's tons of value in that, but it just isn't this type of efficient and effective investment in the people of the firm to both help with recruiting and make sure you've got your future leaders. So the biggest problem really was getting him, not necessarily on board. He understood the value of it. But to get him to just support a lot of these things because he was more like, why should we grow? I kinda want smaller. And that was those the the 2 guys love each other, uh, but they just have this different sense for where they wanna go. So that was probably the biggest issue. But, uh, but we but it worked out. We he went along with it, and and it's it's working out really well. Thank you.

"], ["Interviewer: It's clear that the budgeting and ROI analysis not only enhanced financial management but also influenced strategic decisions on firm growth and service offerings. Given your experience in managing such a significant change, how do you approach the measurement of leadership effectiveness, and what metrics or KPIs do you find most valuable in assessing leadership performance within an organization?  

", "Interviewee: Great questions. Uh, and you're very articulate. Thank you. I wish I could answer as articulately as you do. Uh, with respect to measure and leadership, there's different types of leaders. And here I would look at it as it's it's rare to find somebody who's good at everything you need somebody to be good at at in a professional services firm environment or probably in most environments. Uh, And as a result, you you would ideally have a team of leaders, some of whom were really good at certain things and able to focus on those things and then have other people who could take care of, have the time and the expertise and experience to do some of the other things. So the areas that I think of being very important, uh, I'll I'll mention a few. 1 is people. You you need to be able to create the future leaders of the firm and there's a lot to be involved within that. So I'll I'll keep this at a high level and then maybe you'll have some follow-up questions to go into more detail. Uh, so people are very important. Practice development, working on the business and not just in the business, that's very important. So some of the processes we were talking about, some management tools on the finance side. What are the things I did with Global Legal, that law firm we were just talking about, and in my prior it really throughout my career, was developing the tools and processes necessary to make the the day to day work of the employees lower in risk, way more efficient and effective than than not than not having these tools, which I found very common at the the firms that I've been at. They kinda have different people doing different things, which I really support in terms of creativity. But certain things you wanna standardize, uh, and then, of course, listen to your people and change it so that everybody's using what what is collectively and by leadership agreed to be. This is the most efficient and effective way for us to serve our clients, uh, or to win new work or or to track our our metrics. So I would look at in terms of leadership evaluation, I would look at their performance regarding people, regarding the practice. I would look at business development, uh, in including marketing in that thing. And so how prominent in the market are they? So so people practice business development, marketing. You need somebody to be very good at finances, and then you need everybody to understand finances to some extent. So when I was, uh, at a firm called BDO, I had a team of about a 150 people throughout the country in 15 different offices, and we would have monthly calls. Uh, I mean, I had regional leaders, different partners who that I had hired and and, uh, got admitted to the partnership over, you know, after a number of years. Um, and what we would do is make sure that our people understood the financials So they understood that every hour they worked contributed to the financials in this way. So I would review with them every month the national financials so they could see, okay. Here's where we are in terms of revenue. Here's where we are in terms of gross profit, etcetera. Uh, so finances are very important. And then strategy is very important too, of course, uh, which I would and technology is I mean, all of this stuff is important. So I would look to leaders in all of those categories. If I had to pick a financial metric by which to measure somebody, I would pick in a professional services context. I would probably pick gross profit. Uh, it it just depends on your role. Like, as president of a law firm, I needed to look at the net profit, of course. Uh, but if you're a larger firm, oftentimes, like like, take a BDO, I wasn't responsible directly for the insurance premiums where the firm was paying. And that that was affecting net profit, but not gross profit. So measuring me and the hundreds of other partners at at the the firm on the basis of the insurance premiums wouldn't have made sense. So gross profit is probably the financial metric. But, again, just to wrap up, uh, people practice, business development, market prominence, financials, and strategy slash technology. Thank you.

"], ['Interviewer: Your approach to evaluating leadership across these key areas is quite comprehensive. Given the emphasis on standardizing processes and leveraging technology for efficiency, how do you balance the need for standardization with the potential for innovation within a firm, especially in the legal and professional services industry where tradition often plays a significant role?  

', "Interviewee: That's a great that's a fantastic question. And there's always some tension there. But the key here's a quick story when I started and it was 1993. I was still in law school. I did an internship with with a with pricewaterhousecoopers PWC. And the in the project I was assigned to was the first one of its kind under some new law and nobody had developed any procedures. They told me as an intern read the tax code go out and get the information you need and report back and this was like, I was out there for two three months interviewing software Engineers about what they were doing and how it met the legal requirements or didn't meet the legal requirements. And then I had to quantify the extent to which they were performing certain activities or investing certain costs now in certain types of activities and expenses So I put together some tools from my media use so that I didn't have to for example as I'm interviewing all these people. I wanted to have an agenda so I could make sure the person I'm interviewing new out what I want to talk about before the meeting started. I wanted because I need to get information from him or her about the activities they were performing and how they met the various legal test. I just wanted a template for the interviews so I could ask the questions I need to ask. Also, I needed to document their activities on various projects and that was an activity that I thought I could do or I could maybe do with them or they could conceivably do it if they wanted to so that was something I tried. I just let them know. It's like one of the things we need for purposes of this project is we need to get certain information from your brain and in the documentation at the company. into a memo and I'm happy to interview you I mean we can do it together or I mean here's a template you could use if you want to fill it out and then we could talk about it whatever you want to do and and Thankfully really a lot of them wanted to do it on their own on their own time and they would they would fill it out. I would look at it. And then I'd go back to them with questions I would have because that's you know. A lot less than I expected but some of the time of course there was in for you know garbage in garbage out sort of like they didn't quite get the right information I needed but boy that made it way more efficient. So to make this long story short short order. the I put together these tools. I put a number of other tools as well. Just so I could get my job done. I put all this together and then a manager, you know, I was out on my own this whole time and then I go back into the office where I hadn't been it was like my first time in the office since I was headed with this firm and the firm the manager said hey who told you to put these materials together and you sort of bald me out and I was like, oh shoot. I guess I shouldn't have done that all though. I was thinking I don't know. What I mean, how could I not have put this stuff together just seemed like you know, no brainer. So I was like, I didn't know what to think about it a year later. I interned with the firm for a year part-time during the my last year law school when it ended up working their full-time the following year and I got assigned to one of these projects that I had done the first one of with a number of other people, but I was working on my own. And I and they said well, hey we want you to this project. Here's our materials for for us that we're using nationally on these projects and I'm looking through them and I'm like, oh my gosh, these are the materials I put together and and what I learned from that was that you should always make sure to have a culture. All in which everybody at every level has a voice and has you know, it can can make sure that any even complaints. I mean you and you have to encourage that as a leader. It's like look, I want you to complain. I mean ideally you'd complain and then say hey here's an idea of for fixing my complaint. But you know when you hear about a complaint something's not working right and it could be the employee but it could also just be you need your processes slow or maybe you don't even need to do it in the first place. So you have to have a culture in which everybody feels not only like they can tell you what's wrong what they don't like but that's kind of their job their job is to make their job better and easier and your job is to make sure they feel comfortable doing And so I told that story because I really learned from that that even though the my particular manager had kind of told me I shouldn't have done that. I learned a year later that that was actually very beneficial to that firm. And so I wanted to you know, I was like, okay, I've got to make sure everybody you know, I'm not just gonna be like, okay, here's how we're doing it. We're doing this for the next for the rest of our lives. You've got to make sure your people understand that you didn't hire them just toWant them to become you, I mean your job. I used to tell people, you know, if I had to summarize my job and two words. It's to replace myself, especially in the Legal Professional Services context. Thank you so much.

"], ['Interviewer: Thanks for taking the time to interview with us! The time allotted for our interview has come to an end. We will reach out to you with next steps shortly. Please click the end interview button to end the interview.', 'Interviewee:']]}

candidateBTranscript:
{'pairs': [['Interviewer: Hello and welcome to the AI interview! This interview will consist of basic questions about your background as well as some high-level questions about the skills you listed on your application. Ensure that you minimize long pauses during your responses, otherwise you may be cut off prematurely. Are you ready to start the interview? 
', 'Interviewee: Interview? Yes.

'], ["Interviewer: Great! I see from your resume that you've had extensive experience with marketing operations, particularly in optimizing automation platforms and implementing ABM strategies. Can you walk me through a specific instance where you integrated Salesforce with HubSpot at PlainID, and the challenges you had to overcome?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Um, so I joined Plan ID, and they had a HubSpot and Salesforce set up. There was a sales ops person who had set it up. Um, but I noticed when I was auditing the system that there was a lot of sync errors between HubSpot and Salesforce. Um, and there was a lot of duplicates. Um, so I went through and eliminated all of the sync errors and, uh, eliminated all of the duplicates. I made sure that the leads were flowing through the systems from, uh, our website and our offline campaigns, um, all the way through HubSpot to Salesforce. And, uh, I made sure that the, um, you know, lead tracking was set up properly and leads were getting added to campaigns properly so that we could do multi touch attribution. Yeah. So I would say probably, like, 60 to 70% of leads we're getting through, um, when we were doing offline campaigns, um, before I joined. And, um, you know, I meticulously went through each campaign, um, as we uploaded the leads into the system and make sure that they weren't getting any sync errors so that they could be properly added to Salesforce campaigns. So that, yeah, we could track our marketing results.

"], ["Interviewer: That's a significant improvement in lead tracking and campaign attribution. When you were resolving the sync errors and deduplicating the data, what specific strategies or tools did you use to ensure a smooth integration and data cleanliness between HubSpot and Salesforce?  

", "Interviewee: Yeah. Um, a combination of the dedupe, um, wizard with HubSpot as well as a marketplace software solution that allows you to do bulk deduplication, um, using HubSpot. Um, we had lean data set up on the Salesforce side to do deduplication. Uh, so the problem was in HubSpot, um, when you uploaded a lead that was a duplicate lead in Salesforce. And it wasn't, um, syncing properly. Um, you had to figure out why it wasn't syncing properly, um, using the audit tools in HubSpot. And then, uh, fix those errors so that they could sync. And then you could, um, merge them or dedupe them.

"], ['Interviewer: Interesting approach with the combination of tools. Shifting focus to your work with Full Circle Insights for multi-touch attribution, could you explain how you configured Full Circle Insights within the existing Salesforce and HubSpot setup to track the customer journey more effectively?  

', 'Interviewee: Yeah. We set up 3 models, um, with full circle insights so that we could do multi touch attribution reporting in Salesforce. Um, we used a first touch, last touch, and a multi touch model. And that was, uh, so that we could build reports and dashboards based on these models. Um, we had a multi touch attribution reporting dashboard, um, that allowed you to see, uh, you know, lead first touch, contact first touch, MQL first touch, opportunity first touch, and then, of course, um, you know, the last touch for each one and multi touch for each one. This was really helpful in identifying which campaigns were performing well. We also, um, upgraded our full circle insights instance so that we could include digital touches. And we were implementing that towards the end of my tenure at plan ID.

'], ['Interviewer: The use of different attribution models is quite insightful. When you upgraded to include digital touches, what were the key challenges you faced in capturing and attributing those touches accurately, especially considering the integration with HubSpot for online engagements?  

', "Interviewee: Yeah. Um, some of it was budget constraints and, um, building a business case for it. Some of it was implementation time, um, working with Full Circle. They, uh, helped us implement a AWS or not. I think it was Google Cloud, um, instance so that we could track anonymous, um, users data and then, um, setting up the reporting and campaign automation in Salesforce using their their, um, object tool. So, um, we could track, you know, all of the, um, digital touch points that came in, especially from anonymous visitors. Um, this was all mostly done in Salesforce. Um, so, uh, the HubSpot integration did not exist. It does not exist, um, for full circle insights. But this allowed us to track, you know, the first touch. Uh, somebody comes in from a LinkedIn ad or a, um, Google ad or something like that. If they don't fill out a form, they remain anonymous. "], ["Interviewer: The implementation of Full Circle's digital touch product sounds quite complex yet impactful.
